												In some ways, this game is the perfect metaphor for our lives. Each of us is the little spacecraft and we chase after the light of our dreams. There will be several paths for us to try out on our journey, with the shadow of our doubts slowing us down if we let it. We will inevitably crash and burn many... many times into obstacles that came out of ♥♥♥♥ing nowhere and there will be that one stage that will seem impossible. However, if we have the courage to press that 'retry' button, then eventually we will beat the game. Just remember to never lose sight of your dream, and don't let the sun set on you before you get to the end. Praise the sun. 10/10

content:
er 10, 2013
												It's like a crazy minimalist hybrid of Star Fox/F-Zero crossed with Super Hexagon's speed and reflex driven twitch aspects.  My only real complaints are the bugs at the moment with achievements and some other stuff.  I liked the older leaderboard stle they had in previous versions, and the soundtrack could be a lot better and perfect the experience.  Overall, great game and I'd highly recommend it if you're into this sort of thing.  Has great level editing tools as well as what will be a great user-created level portal.  I'm not a fan of "luck-based" procedural generated levels but hopefully that can be eliminated by user-created levels at some point.  I'd also like a static leaderboard alongside the daily leaderboard, for best players overall.  And hopefully in time all of this can be worked out in some way.  But yeah, go buy it, one of the best indie titles to release on Steam recently and worth the time and money.

												This game is so addictive. How addicitive you ask? So addictive that you will keep saying "one more go" after smashing against a wall.Race The Sun reminds me of an old flash game that I used to play in College years ago, it was called Tunnel Maze Game and your objective was to dodge and jump obstacles that popped up at you, giving you a split second to react while your character surfed within a tunnel. If you know the game I am talking about then you will enjoy this game.Gameplay wise, not every retry will be the same, meaning you could initially learn a portion of a region and then next try find yourself going a completely different way or into another area. The great thing about this game though is that the world will change every 24 hours, meaning it is forever changing. Not only that but it is user content friendly, meaning you can create and publish your own worlds for others to try.Overall, if you are into games that test your reflexes or you have that determination to try and get a better score or do better than the last try. This game is for you.

content:
26, 2014
Race the Sun is an impressive test of your reflexes & concentration skills reminiscent of classic forward-scrolling 3D shooters like Star Fox. Before the sun disappears, your solar craft must make it as far as possible without hitting anything. At the same time, trying to stay in the light & grab as many power-ups, tris or wormholes across the landscape, to boost you along as fast as possible. There's a fantastic sense of speed building up the longer you survive, often flying past objects so close you could touch it (and sometimes mistakenly do lol!).Lighting effects of the sun streaming rays of light through the various shapes of the artifically inspired worlds looks awesome, while also being a key mechanic functionally in the game design!The world is randomly regenerated every 24hrs to provide new challenging combinations, plus in-between there is plenty of community maps to try on the Workshop. There are also specific challenges to level-up & upgrade your default craft to work towards longer term.  Some of these are really hard!Great to play on the big screen (in your lounge room), for a brief daily distraction (since games can be very quick indeed sometimes) :) or even a longer session where you reach for the clouds & conquer your (or friends) high scores! There are some tough achievements & a game plus mode for the hardcore out there.Race the Sun is easy to pick up but hard to put down... while always striving for that elusive 'high score' just over the horizon!Menus are a bit strange to navigate with a controller & the bright white tones can overwhelm, but other than these minor factors, this is a top quality & very addictive little indie title!If you enjoyed reading this review, please follow True Blue Reviews for more recommendations!

content:
6, 2014
												☺ "Just one more go..." Gameplay.☺ Good controls.☺ A new level to race on every day!☹ Visually and Audibly Repetitive.☹ No access to previous levels.Recommended for fans of arcade racers, twitch or avoidance games.Race the Sun is a minimalist racing game that puts you in charge of an agile solar powered craft and its your job to keep rushing onwards, avoiding obstacles and the shade as you hurtle towards the horizon as the Sun that provides your power, steadily does the same.You'll crash, often, but not because of sloppy controls or unfair difficulty - most likely a case of being in the wrong place at the wrong time or because you reacted a little too slowly. A simple tap of a button and you'll be back to racing almost instantly, providing a very arcadey experience without the need to carry a bag full of coins.An interesting feature of Race the Sun is the level you play on changes each day (unfortunately, you can't replay levels from previous days). This provides a fair amount of content as long as you revisit the game often, although the visuals and audio does begin to get a little repetitive.If things aren't hard enough for you, there is a brutal Apocalypse mode that throws more obstacles at you at a faster pace and there is Steam Workshop integration allowing you easy access to some great player made levels.While the game suits quick play sessions, you'll have to keep an eye on the Sun outside as well as ingame as it instils a feeling of "Just one more run..." as you zip around, picking up power ups and score multipliers and attempting to beat your last run or achieve some of the challenges (such as completing a region while only turning left) to level up and unlock a few abilities to help you do even better.A great arcade racer!

r 27, 2015
												Race the Sun is a very nice little game to play when you have nothing to do with yourself.It's very easy to learn, but like most things, a bit more difficult to master. You have to get as far as you can along the map, while avoiding deadly obstacals, before the sun goes down. While trying to get the highest score you can, you can pick up boosters that will temporarily stop the sun's slow descent. There are four different maps that you can play on. You start with the first one and can unlock the second and third ones by leveling up. If you want the fourth, you have to buy it. I have played and enjoyed the first three, but I haven't tried out the last one. All of the maps randomize every 24 hours, so the layout is slightly different each day.I play my own music when gaming, but the soundtrack for Race the Sun is something I wouldn't mind listening to. And if you don't enjoy it, there is always the mute button. In the end, I would recommend it to anybody who is thinking about buying it.

												Overview: Arcade Racer focused on avoiding obstaclesThe Good:+The game goes on forever, the goal is not only how far you can go but how many points you can get. The premise is that your ship is solar powered, thus staying in the sunlight keeps you going. The sun slowly goes down creating more shadows.  Powerups can extend your time. + Every 24 hours the course is reset. After completing them your ship gets upgraded. +VERY addicting, the game has the "just one more time" feeling to it. +Steamworkshop is intregrated very nicely with a variety of different maps to try out. +The game has a unique and simplistic artstyle to it. As the sun sets it creates a really nice setting. After playing some of the user generated maps you really see some of the verstatily of the engine and graphics despite how simple it is. +Hard mode to really test you to the limit....if you find the main game to easy.The Bad:-  You will get frustrated....a lot. ConclusionThis is a really fun and simple game was a simple premise and works wonderfully due to the randomness of the world. Its a game you can keep going back to and play in short sessions.

number of helpful: 25 of 29 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
y 19, 2014
Race The Sun is an adrenaline rush the likes of which few other games can compare! The whoosh as you soar past objects, the intensity as the sun threatens to disappear past the horizon, and the unbelievable moments of triumph when you make it through in one piece are but small bits of what makes for an extremely exhilarating experience.Your goal is simple: pilot a futuristic solar powered flying-craft at breakneck speeds, dodging obstacles and attempting to get as far as you can before the sun inevitably sets. What turns RtS from a simple detraction into an addiction is the execution. Every aspect has an unprecedented level of refinement, from the effortless maneuvering of your vehicle to the expertly placed obstructions which become increasingly complex and challenging the further you progress, show a clear attention to detail and an superb sense of direction by the developers.Aside from chasing the leaderboards, there are also 25 levels of skill based objectives for you to complete, which unlock upgrades and details to outfit your craft with. It took me about five hours to clear them all, at which point you truly begin your climb up the leaderboards. Although the game does lose a bit of its drive without these challenges to complete, having a newly remixed world every day (complete with daily leaderboards) still gives a reason to keep coming back for more, which is made even easier by how well RtS works as a pickup and play game, while still providing enough depth to make longer sessions just as enjoyable (those looking for an extra challenge will definitely find it in the ultra-hard Apocalypse mode).Lastly I can't stress enough how unexpectedly amazing the presentation is. The textures themselves might be basic, but there is an elegance in RtS's barren landscape that works amazingly well with how fast you will be soaring through it. The sparse use of color becomes even more important, outlining oncoming obstacles and highlighting power-ups in your peripheral vision that might otherwise be lost to more robust graphical effects. The stark contrast between light and shadow plays a key role in creating a sense of dread whenever you cross into one, letting you know the end is nigh if you don't get out of there fast. A great score and excellent sound effects round out the package, which words really can't do any justice to.It only took one round for me to get hooked to Race the Sun. Developer Flippfly absolutely nailed it and created something that truly astounded me, perhaps more so than any other game the year it released. I'm just going to end this by saying you need to play this for yourself! It's a breathtaking game that I desperately want to share with others, and one that deserves to be played by a far larger crowd than those who have managed to discover it. Don't let it slip by you, the sun is already setting.You can read more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

content:
2015
A peaceful runner-style game where you guide a solar powered craft through an ever more shadowy obstacle course.From experience of driving towards the sun, you wouldn't think much of a game that focuses on flying towards the sun. Why would I want to do that? The sun is bright and makes my eyes hurt. This game is a fun way to use our imagination, and enjoy ourselves in a solar powered aircraft. If it helps, presume that you are wearing sunglasses, perhaps even fashionable ones. Do you feel cool? Are you prepared to look directly at bright lights? Fantastic.I imagine this takes place in a sad, dystopic future devoid of fine art or literature, where fossil fuels and other natural resources have been exhausted. All that remains are a few mostly abandoned cities, the wilds between, and due to the political turmoil of resource starvation, the world is on the eve of annihilation. Enter our protagonist, a strong silent individual. You're transporting yourself and a motley crew of rogues, miscreants, and iconoclast scientists aboard a solar-powered plane last-ditch effort to survive the imminent nuclear annihilation and attempt to prolong the death of a dying world much as a doctor extends the lives of those with chronic diseases. Specifically, you have a technology, a solar powered technology that is also built into your very aircraft. This technology opens portals to new worlds, and any one of them could be the paradise awaiting the future of humanity. Occasionally a bird approaches to aid you on your quest, as if nature itself is encouraging you in  your quest.Every once in a while you find structure capable of powering these warp gates and moving through them transports you to strange, fanciful, wonderful, and potentially terrible lands. Are any of these places inhabitable? It is unlikely, but any leap into the unknown could eventually show you the future of our species. There is such limited time though. This is certainly the last day before the missiles launch, and that means that when your plane falls to the ground at dusk, the world is lost.Controls are simple. You turn left, you turn right, you jump when you've got the right power up, and there's also a powerup which allows you to accidentally crash into a wall without dying. Throughout you pick up stars that increase your speed. You may note that speed will keep the sun higher on the horizon for longer periods of time.  You can do a barrel roll as well.If the sun sets you run out of power and die. If you collide with sufficient force, you die. The difficulty ramps up nicely as well, so that death, which comes to us all, may always be delayed a bit longer. There's a couple of starting levels of differing difficulty, and a workshop with extras, as well as an expansion that I have not tried as of yet. You level up by doing things like not turning left for a while, or being good at not hitting stuff, or collecting a lot of stuff in the air. These levels give you things like a magnet that makes it so you pick up stuff easier, or a battery that lets you survive in the shadows better. You can also put stickers on your plane, which alone with the portals is the closest thing to visual texture in the game. This game is grey scale polygons everywhere. Grey pyramids? Probably trees or mountains depending on scale? Grey rectangular prisms I imagine are buildings. There are some that look like shrubbery or boulders. The aesthetic is minimalist and produced a light feeling of ennui. There is quality lighting and shadow, which is fantastic as these are actually used as gameplay mechanics. Different modes have differing color schemes, and the apocalyptic mode is especially pleasant to view.The sounds are quite nice. The music is of limited quantity, but the quality is apparent and it elicits an appropriate response.If you have an imagination, or just want something of variable relaxation and pace, something of an original concept, then this could be quite an enjoyable original addition for you. Personally I gave it my full attention for several relaxing enjoyable hours.This review has been produced in accordance with green technologies, specifically the aeronautical technologies behind solar powered propulsion. These machines are often light weight fully electric craft and represent an important engineering challenge for developing technologies for cleaner, cheaper aircraft. This review is a locally grown, ethically sourced product of the Original Curator Group

content:
3, 2014
												The idea of a minuscule studio putting out a game that will potentially entrance millions with its easy accessibility and well-graduated complexity curve proves that there is still room in the market for the little guy. Race the Sun is not only a fun little addiction but hopefully also a harbinger of the return of boutique developers.If Race The Sun’s tracks remain as consistently well-paced and tiered as the raft of stages we’ve experienced to date, then it can be considered a success rather than an experiment: a confident genre hybrid worthy of your time and patience because who knows, today could be your day.Race the Sun is very close to a perfect pick-up-and-play game, except for the bit where it’s very hard not to keep playing once you’ve started. A quick break easily turns into one more attempt, trying to plot a different course over the cluttered plains, maximizing Tri collection while minimizing the risk of turning into a cloud of debris.An original take on the arcade time-trial formula.Race the Sun is an elegant endeavor, pairing slick action and stiff challenge with systems that make you want to come back day after day.

number of helpful: 11 of 11 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
y 14, 2016
												You have probably heard the expression "Less is more". And it pretty much applies here because this game is quite simple with minimalistic design. But just because it is that way doesn't mean that you will be able to complete it in few hours or feel that there's something missing. Let me tell you more about it.Let's start with the story. There is not other way  to put it but to say that there isn't one. Yep, it is simple as that. Basically you are piloting a spacecraft fueled by solar energy and the sun is your death timer. And for this game it couldn't have been better. On the bright side you don't need to worry about the story being to complex, bad or uninteresting. This game is more about highest scores and tense gameplay. But let's talk about those simplistic graphics. When I launched the game for the first time it looked boring for few seconds but not much more than that because simple graphics can be good in its own right. In my opinion the game should be fun and engaging first and only then it should be an eye candy. There are of course games that are an eye candy first but we're not talking them right now. The beauty of the game in the arrangement of the obstacles, it's in clouds, in shapes and in the variety of all those things. But we'll talk about those in detail later on. For now let's talk gameplay. This being basically a racing game where you, uh... race the sun and trying not to let it set involves high speed. You need to be as fast as you can and there are things that make you go faster like boosts and you will have to find those boosts if you don't want to run out of energy. There are other bonuses in the game as well. Jumping for example that can help you avoid certain death. Or the one that is basically an extra life that can be crucial in the later stages of the game. And there are 'tris' that increase your points multiplier. Although you can complete first few stages without too much maneuvering you will have to change your course if you want to find any of these. There are many challenges and achievements too that will push your comprehension of what is possible in this game. The game does no have difficulty settings but it definitely gets harder and harder as you move further from region to region. And the obstacles change too. Ranging for rocks to mountains, windmills, falling skyscrapers and more.  And there is one more thing that made all of the components into one hell of a symphony - music. It amazingly matches the game. It's also simplistic and changes based on where you are in the game and the surroundings. I can't say that there's too much variety with music but for me it glues everything together quite nicely. So should you buy it? Well, I got mine for free during some promotion but it was on my wishlist so I would have bought it anyway and had my money worth. You should buy this game if you don't really give a crab about the story and you don't mind spending countless hours trying to complete the next region or you're into high scores and online leaderboards. content:
21
 Overview  Race The Sun is an atypical single player racing game that puts you in control of a geometric solar powered craft on a never-ending, futile journey to keep a fully charged battery and keep the sun from setting. As you race towards the always distant sun, you’ll have to circumvent an ever-changing obstacle course and collect power-ups and energy boosts to keep the sun in the sky for as long as you can. Watch out though, as one frontal collision and your run is over and back to the beginning you go.The game itself comes at you from a very minimalist approach, though there’s a bit more to the game at first glance. There’s some real satisfying work that goes into completing it and it really kept me hooked, but Race The Sun suffers from longevity issues which makes leaving a lasting impression on you difficult to master. The main game, as mentioned above, you pilot a winged solar craft through courses that change once every 24hrs. While many of the obstacles will remain similar at first glance, the position at which they come to you, the order and the location of the power-ups will all be different each day. There’s an in-game counter stating when you can expect a new course to play on. This is a wonderful device that keeps the content fresh without having to constantly release DLC content. The game, to an extent, creates it for you. As you proceed through these levels, you’ll be given side challenges that will help level up your craft. These can range from how many icons you collect [called tris], your bonus multiplier, how many power-ups you use and so forth. They are scaled from a simple easy to hard scale and the value of tokens earned is based on that scale. As you level up, you’ll gain new, permanent abilities that you can toggle on and off based on your play style or the type of challenge you’re working on; these range from a magnet to draw in tris, the ability to hold additional powers like shields and jump abilities, a larger battery pack and more. There are no traditional difficulty settings in Race The Sun, but instead different game modes that stand in their place. Your typical playthrough would fall under the “Normal” category, while you can unlock an “apocalypse” mode; the game’s version of “hard”. In juxtaposition to those, there is also a casual mode with no sun that allows you to just play the game in a stress free environment, as well as a top-down version.I never ran into many problems while playing. There were some instances of FPS drops that were really irritating on such a minimalist game; a few times it cost me my run. They didn’t stop me from playing, but it wasn’t a problem I was ever able to locate and fix either. The only other issue I have with the game was the difficulty spike between normal runs and the heightened “apocalypse” mode. I consider myself a junkie for difficulty, but even as I learned the ins and outs of the courses and their routines, it felt far too scaled upward to remain as enjoyable. I found myself completely ignoring this aspect of the game, which is a shame.The height of the game’s enjoyment came, for me, with doing the in-game challenges. However, once you fully level up your craft you no longer have a list to work on, making the game fall back on just racing the sun. While fun, there felt like a chunk of purpose was removed from the game when I had nothing else to strive for other than my own personal record. That nearly tangible feeling of excitement vanished just like the challenges did. Aside from the Steam achievements, I no longer had a reason to keep playing…so I didn’t. I wish I had a reason to go back.  Pros   A great test of reflexes and skill if you enjoy racing-type games. Friendly UI setup. Easy to drop in and out of for short or long sessions. Lovely art style with a good use of colors and B&W canvases.  There is a level editor, though it takes some practice. Cons  
 There are instances of FPS drops for some users. Lacks a proper end game to keep user presence and longevity. The “apocalypse” setting can be daunting for some users with no way to adjust it.Overall, I really enjoyed Race The Sun. The simplicity in its design balanced out the sharp difficulty curve as you learned to play the game. It balanced it’s color scheme and rigged layout with splashes of color and smooth [for the most part] gameplay. While I wish there was more to keep me going back, I enjoyed every minute of it.

number of helpful: 11 of 12 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
er 10, 2013
												I've loved this game since I came across it a few months back, and was absolutely over the moon when the dev's behind it announced they'd finally made it through the greenlight process and were releasing it on steam.So what do you need to know about it?Well, let me ask you this.  When was the last time you really remember doing the old "sega" lean?  (seriously if you're too young to remember that, don't even ask) In my case, before Race the Sun, I'd have had to say, "I don't remember" - seriously, it really had been that long since any game was immersive enough to make me lean in time to my movements on the screen, like that was going to have any effect on my ability to steer.Race the Sun had me doing it within seconds of trying it out, and does so with the kind of regularity which is as refreshing as it is tragic, lol.Under the hood, it's a basic time trial racer... but it feels more open than that.  Graphically it's an awesome kick back into retro gaming, whilst in itself being pretty smooth and well done.Levels are a mix of custom creations, both by the devs and other players, and proceedurally generated goodness, and the maps change on a daily basis (at the time of writing) keeping things fresh and meaning that no one player can grind their way to an unbeatable position on the leaderboard for a given map.Like your first hit of a Class A substance, Race the Sun is incredibly easy to pick up and start, but very hard to put down for any significant period of time, and for me at least, has become one of my go-to games for when I want a nice, enjoyable game to chill out playing without needing to become stupidly focused or remember whole codices of ingame stats and background info.As a final thought, all I can add is that I've gotten far more bang for my buck with this game than I have with way too many other titles in the past, and unlike a lot of them, I know I'll be back to play it from time to time.

												This is a runner game based on boost pickups to prolong your run before the sun sets down, which leads to running out of energy and slowing down to a halt. You initially learn the ropes by completing challenges, and level up to unlock new features and cosmetics as well. I highly recommend focusing on hitting max level before considering to do anything else, also since you'll get to experience the most optimized way to play the game.You get one seed to play with per 24h with its own leaderboards, which is fine, since the game's concept is early route planning and endless avoidance with quick decisions on your feet. The maps have set patterns, so even if you're not that great at video games, you can still memorize them and act on instinct after you get familiar enough.Overall a great game, good experience, would recommend to everyone and anyone who looks for both a casual or a challenging experience.

er 13, 2013
												To look at this game's store page you'd think, "looks kinda lame" however you'd be just as completely and totally WRONG as I was.  First up, and I'm not gonna lie to you here, this game is addictive.  And when I say it's addictive I don't mean, "oh what a nice little game, I'll play for a few minutes then get on with my day..."  No, it's more like the kind of addiction that grabs you instantly and never lets go.  I'd say it's impossible to play, "just one round."  No no.... you'll be like oh man I gotta do that again, I know I can do it better.  Wait wait... I know where I screwed up just one more round.  Oh man, I can't let that stop me.  Just a little more."But DJ so what if it's addictive it just looks like a silly time waster and I can find those for free."  Once again your dead wrong.  What the game lacks in graphics it more than double makes up for in gameplay.  It's a racing game that gives you just as much thrills and spills as any racing game out there.  It's a game of dodging stuff that will leave you holding your breath as you narrowly miss that wall with a feeling of relief when you do.  It's a game to challenge you to beat your friends high scores that's just as enjoyable to achieve as the best competitive multiplayer game out there.  It's a game about change as each new day brings a new map to challenge your friends to.  It's a creators paradise where you can create maps and challenges for all your friends and community.  Belive me when I say, this game is a whole lot more than it looks.You honestly can't go wrong adding this gem of a game to your game library.  Buy it when it's cheap, but even at $10.00 I'd still say it's more than worth it.  It'll be your best spent money all week.

content:
er 12, 2013
												Race The Sun is one of those endless runners we've seen hundreds of times before on our mobile phones. But we've rarely seen one appear on Steam. It's because Race The Sun is stylish, fun and addictive, and not necessarily in that order.You basically steer a ship across a randomly generated world with tons of objects to avoid and power-ups to collect. It's fast paced and objective based. Well, it's not required, really, but it helps you upgrade your ship later on and might make your life a little easier. There are always 3 random objectives to complete, and with each objective you complete you'll earn 1 (easy objective) to 3 (harder objective) upgrade points. Upgrades can be a higher multiplier right from the start or the ability to store 2 power-ups instead of 1.While racing you have to collect yellow power-ups to keep raising the sun. Your ship is energy powered and staying in the shadows for too long will slow you down, resulting in a lower score (because, obviously, you can't collect items as quickly anymore). And if the sun goes down it's game over, too.In the end I was pleasantly surprised by Race The Sun. I grew tired of endless runners a long time ago, but the combination of random worlds, power-ups and objectives make this game feel fresh somehow. Praise the sun ![Rating: 78/100]

number of helpful: 48 of 87 people (55%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
ber 17, 2015
												Race the Sun is a type of forever runner game that has you piloting a flightless hover ship as it glides along a minimalist desert of walls, triangle spikes and blocks that fall over. Your ship is solar powered and going too far into shadows will slow you down and with the sun setting in the horizon itself, that turns the sun into a timer. Slamming into an object is failure, but you can graze an edge of your ship and be fine for a while.On the surface, there's nothing wrong with the game, its easy to play, left and right to steer and well left and right to steer. It takes a moment for your ship to shift. The controls are simple and work well with a keyboard or 360 controller. You can do things like barrel rolls if you steer too far one way then hard turn it the other way. You can even unlock a single jump and other upgrades for your ship like a magnet that draws in orbs.The game is shallow and even worse it relies on only one level for the most part. This single level resets itself each day. New day, new level. Other than that, you can unlock two additional levels and even play a credits level that has you flying under the credits in what feels like a flat open space with no challenge rather than an actual level.Because its just one level, and the game never modifies itself, it makes the game feel like its more about memory than skill. Sure it takes skill to move between two falling blocks, but it takes memory to remember that you can just drive around the wall to a much easier path.Each level consists of different regions and each region seems to be a loop of itself twice. Well loop with some extras thrown in. As if someone copied and pasted then added some extra fluff. Between each region a white bird will zig-zag and drop four orbs one direction and four orbs another direction. Then it will drop a sun orb which surges your ship to its top speed. You'll find several blue orbs, sun orbs and green jump orbs throughout each level. There are ramps here and there that let you catch big air, falling blocks and shadows to slow you down. The funny thing is you can jump off a ramp high over orbs and it will still collect them if you touch the beam of light over them. Perhaps that's an unlocked feature. Its about as bare bones as it comes to runners.You'll find portal gates that for whatever reason send you into space where you have a view from the cockpit. The game plays much slower and everything is black. You get to see a galactic space battle in black and white as you fly through it dodging lesser vessels as they zoom by. It feels out of place at best and only makes the game feel a lot easier going so slow. If we're still piloting the same ship when we're in the portal, am I still powered by the sun? Where is the sun in space? I sure can't see the sun.In the main game itself you can change the camera view from a behind chase cam to a bumper view. Inside the galactic space battle, you're stuck in the cockpit, pressing the camera view button shifts the view by a few pixels. its odd that the game shifts at all when its that small of a difference.There's a leveling up mechanic that has you accomplishing three goals to get to the next level. Getting to level eleven and twenty-five unlock new levels, but to get there you'll need to do things like jump ten times and do twenty barrel rolls in a single play. The further you go, the more challenging these goals become. Its definitely a way to add some longevity to a shallow game that feels like little to no effort was put in. The entire game feels like no effort was put in and its really the players that need to put time into the game. I want to play here, not work here.To the game's credit, it looks great. The minimalist approach enhances the game and my enjoyment of it. It makes good use of a dynamic lighting system. The sun casts shadows, although some of the shadows seem to be painted on hazards to hurt your time. Even with a sun, some levels are just gray. Yes indeed, two-hundred and fifty-five shades of gray monochromatic action. Of course a level can be any color, I just seem find gray levels.Race the Sun has a level editor and Steam workshop integration, so you can always find new levels. I took one look at the level editor, saw how deep it is and then closed it. I've learned so many other level editors that its tough to justify putting time into this one. The real problem is why is that our job as players to make new levels? Sure its fun to create levels, publish them and rate them, but as a developer why are we stuck with one level per day on the computer version of what is essentially a mobile game? That sort of mechanic is what keeps people coming back and sitting through ads day after day and not people that paid money.Speaking of paying money and mobile ports, on the start screen, they have DLC, the soundtrack and the mobile version to buy. That's understandable, a lot of bigger games, non indie games with shareholders often use this tactic right front and center and fans let them know it. Race the Sun is immune to this and people still manage to love the game for its brief and addictive gameplay. For a game that sells a soundtrack, why is there only one song? This whole game seems like a big cash grab.There's so little here that its a starvation and so the game keeps you coming back for more with daily courses. You keep coming back to get your moneys worth, to get that quick shallow fix and move on with life knowing that level you spent an hour memorizing and mastering will never appear again. Your work, effort and bragging rights are replaced by tomorrow's level. A chance to wake up and do it all over again.While I hate to judge a game for everything but the game, there's just not much game here. you go left, you go right, take a ramp. remember what you did wrong. Wash; rinse; repeat.

Product received for free
												I downloaded this game from steam when it was free. After a bit of gameplay experience, the thing I want to say about this game is the following:This is a really simple game, simplistic graphics, not too complex gameplay. You are controlling an aircraft which is powered by sunlight. You constantly have to follow the sun to keep you powered up and what that means basically is you have to fly through different terrain at extremely high speed without crashing. Sounds easy right? It actually is quite an easy and relaxing game. The graphics are simple but that doesnt mean they are not nice. They are minimalistic. And the game has a great soundtrack. And the whole atmosphere gives a kind of "after humanity" feeling. The controls are easy and the map is changing every 24 hours so you wont get bored of it easily. Unless you find the gameplay itself boring. And there are also quite an amount of challenges up to date.Overall (I want to start with the cons)Cons:- The gameplay might be too simple for some people- Can get repetitive- All challenges can be accomplished in around a dayPros:- I find the graphics (personally) satisfying- Relaxing gameplay- The game has a unique feeling- Nice atmosphere- Even if you run out of in game challenges, steam achievements will keep you fresh- 24 hrs changing map- Easy to do, hard to master- The overall concept is great and it worksI would definitely recommend at least giving a shot to this game if you want something relaxing yet challenging in your inventory.

content:
6, 2014
												This game has a very bitter aftertaste.If you just want play an easy game on the normal mode for a maximum 3 hours this game seems to be fair enough, but don't expect too much to happen during that time, if you already decided to buy it.Also, if you just want to chill out a bit and don't care about scores or achievements, this game might be a good choice and you don't have to read on.The game looks very nice on its screenshots, but it is the most monotonous game I've ever played. I don't want to say that this game is horrible, but even without my hopes and expectations I had when seing the screens of this game, I am sure that I still wouldn't recommend it. It is just not my cup of tea and I'm going to tell you why...I like racing games, especially the fast and highly unrealistic ones I played in old times. Obviously this game is nothing like that. To be honest, I expected it to be somewhat like StarWing (SNES, 1993), because it almost looks like it. I bought this game, because its "fast" gameplay and interesting look seemed promising. Well, this game did not meet my expectation in any way. Please do not get fooled by the screenshots that imply that there is a variety of space themed or interesting levels. Those are temporary warp zones and not even fun ones to play either.At some point this game can be fast, but is it any good when you cannot manouver fast enough to react to certain objects (not even with the steering upgrade)? The controls are extremely limited. You are only able to steer left and right, a button to activate your power-up and that's IT. NO turning your vehicle upside down or sideways to fly through narrow spaces. Actually, you are able to perform an aileron roll (commonly refered to as barrel roll), but it does absolutely nothing besides reminding you of how awesome it would be to quit the game and play a different one. You are not even able to steer your vehicle up or down, while in midair. Even the rare and short space zones cannot be navigated 3Dimensionally. The control settings say that you can map "up" and "down", but it's only for the menu (what a freakin' joke). You can only jump, which is one of three power-ups. In this game nothing spectacular or exciting will happen, due to limited gameplay features..To be fair, the normal game mode is very easy and to a certain extend fun to play, but if you wanted to go deeper into what the game holds in store for you, you have to play its Apocalypse mode, which except for the beginning of each level is absolutely random and requiers 50% of pure luck and 50% of skill. Besides I really don't want to get started about what's wrong with that game mode and I only want to say that it is frustrating NOT because it's difficult, but because UNPREDICTABLE level elements can ruin a good run instantly with cheap deaths. I mean, of course you get better and learn certein patterns that might repeat and yet still a high share of luck remains. Not even trial and error will get you further, but rather plain patience and multiple runs. For all those achievement hunters out there: obtaining the hardest achievement in the game is not too hard, but it can be so boring that it makes you actually wish for a breath of fresh air outside, watching a real sunset for over an hour, rather than playing this monotonous game. Really, there's not much variety to be discovered in this game. It's just a game with unused potential. I like its cover picture though...

content:
er 11, 2013
												Race the Sun is a brilliant little endless runner. This is a genre that I often want to like but frequently fail to do so as the execution never quite works for me. But in Race the Sun it does. The 24 hour world resets strike a great balance between getting the chance to practice and perfect something, while always having something new to try each day. Also, unlike the side scrollers in the genre, RtS offers a degree of movement freedom that actually scratches something of an exploration itch in me.

content:
y 17
												Rated "Awesome" for everyone.Most of my playtime with Race The Sun has been via the Humble Store (DRM-free + Steam key) version. So don't take my Steam stats at face value.As racers go, Race The Sun is as good as it gets. Race The Sun offers a broad appeal by being easy to learn and difficult to master. Race The Sun also ashews the usual 'cut throat' approach to competition by letting you compete against yourself, THEN showing you how your performance stacks up on Leaderboards. Courses that are randomly generated every twenty-four hours keep things fresh. Toss in low hardware requirements, gamepad support, and cross-platform (Win/Mac/Linux) compatibility and its accessibility is unmatched. Race The Sun is every bit worth owning whether you're a racing fan or not.

												I got this game because it was free for a day and had steam cards. After playing it I'm considering buying the DLC.Mechanically its very straightforward -  you steer a solar powered ship and see how far you can go. As your travel you collect power-ups while trying to avoid the shadows and not crash. If you survive long enough the sun sets and your race ends.While playing you have three goals to complete in order to level up and unlock more options. Some of these are really annoying (like only turning left), whereas others are simple (like hit X objects). The options vary and can be different game modes or unlocked items to aid your flight.The track changes each day which makes this an excellent casual play game. Its also fairly addictive, I frequently found myself thinking "Just one more try and I'll make it to the next region or complete the next goal."I wouldn't want to pay full price for it, but I recommend it when its bundled or on sale.

												In some ways, this game is the perfect metaphor for our lives. Each of us is the little spacecraft and we chase after the light of our dreams. There will be several paths for us to try out on our journey, with the shadow of our doubts slowing us down if we let it. We will inevitably crash and burn many... many times into obstacles that came out of ♥♥♥♥ing nowhere and there will be that one stage that will seem impossible. However, if we have the courage to press that 'retry' button, then eventually we will beat the game. Just remember to never lose sight of your dream, and don't let the sun set on you before you get to the end. Great game to play every now and then. Really fun and fast paced.Graphics looks minimalistic with just mostly grey but it is an interesting style and doesn't distract from the action.The Soundtrack is good but there sadly aren't that many songs. You can buy it here.Controlls feel very tight.There are also 3 different mode:Normal (which you will play most of the time) Apocalypse (when you want more challenge) Labyrinth (a more slower paced mode,which allows you to have more time to decide where to go with a small amount of puzzlesZen Mode (accessable only with the DLC, this is a relaxing mode without any presure or challengeThe levels/world changes every 24h so you have enought time to try to get a high score for the day but also enought divercity so it doesn't get boring that quickly.Overall i think it is a great game for all ages and you should definetly check it out

content:
23, 2016
												A hidden gem! No seriously; if you like "endless running" games, then this is an excellent choice.The minimalistic visuals are beautiful on their own, managing to create some wonderful vistas. The main interest you'll have in this game, though, is the gameplay. While seemingly simple and repetitive, if you're into games like these, then you'll probably not end up bored.It does one thing, and it does it really, really well. You're a solar craft that travels the landscape, avoiding objects and shadows in your way. The sun is, almost in the literal sense of the word, your death timer, as your solar craft will quickly drain battery if the sun goes down, or if you spend too much time in shadows (damn you clouds! *shakes fist angrily toward the sky*).Race The Sun features a daily challenge, in the form of a randomly generated map, leaderboards, a pretty nice soundtrack, and some basic customization of the craft. Customization includes various wing decals, as well as the more important attachments that enhance your solar craft in many different ways. These are unlocked throughout the 25 levels, that you in turn gain through more or less difficult objectives given to you while playing.It's great when you don't know what to do with yourself, when you're coming home tired from work or school, or when you just want to relax. For me personally, it works great as both an exciter and a relaxer, depending on my mood and the situation.If you'd rather play your own music, instead of the in game one, I'll have you know it works well with almost anything from death metal to drum and bass.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
11
												You play as an aircraft, powered by the sun, racing through procedurally created regions. The sun is ever setting, and by collecting speed boosts, you can give yourself more time to race the sun through ever more hectic regions. Along the way are other powerups and combo tris to let your score climb ever higher, as long as you can keep up your speed so the sun doesn't set. If the sun goes down, if you drive in shadows, if you bump objects, you slow down, and if you stop, you die. The game can get very intense in later levels as you make hairpin turns on twitch reactions, diving from speed boost to speed boost in a frantic attempt to keep the sun juuuust over the horizon. There's also world portals that will teleport you to user-made levels, some of which are detah traps, and others which are just pure bonus score increasers and will send your score sky high.As you play the game you can unlock challenges that, when completed, will unlock new decals and cosmetics, as well as upgrade the powerups you can get, or let you carry more of them. A new level is generated every 24 hours, so leaderboards are changing constantly, and there's always a new level to try to route yourself through. The game also boasts an extra difficult Apocalypse mode, and a slower, more puzzley Labyrinth mode, for extra challenges. There's also a no-sun-timer DLC available if that's what you're interested in, too.Truth be told, I don't know if the game is worth ten dollars. It's really fun and engaging, and new levels every day encourage constant improvements and score increasing on new leaderboards, but at the end of the day, it really is something that you could play on any old games website with flash games.If you're interested in Endless Runners, and like them, defintiely give the game a go!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
y 3
												For all the grand adventures and intricate experiences that video games have to offer nowadays, sometimes it’s the older and simpler ideas that stick in the mind the most. You may share similar memories to me; ones of heading to websites such as Miniclip, and playing those little games which consisted of dodging and weaving a spaceship round the many blocks and obstacles that came hurtling in your direction. It was good, clean fun. Well, Race the Sun doesn’t really try and disguise the fact that at its core it’s basically offering more of the same. Still, that’s not a bad thing – the concept remains fun even today, whether you are wearing the rose tinted glasses of nostalgia or not.  It continues to be satisfying to watch your score go up and up as you expertly weave your way through the narrowest of gaps, all the while experiencing that jolt in your stomach as you brush far too close to your death. Even when you inevitably turn into a fine mist, the feeling you can always do better compels you to hit that restart button and so through the whole process again. Race The Sun manages to easily pull all those emotions out of you, but goes on to amplify them via the added spice of challenging you to stay one step ahead of a setting sun, all via the means of collecting certain power –ups and staying out of the shadows. This makes it so you have to be taking more risks if you want to survive for any extended period of time, meaning those exciting near death moments come at such a rapid pace it certainly keeps the blood pumping. It’s a cool little mechanic.That’s not the only thing different that Race the Sun adds to the table, either. There’s also a list of challenges to complete, varying from reaching certain distances to performing a number of risky manoeuvres, where success slowly levels you up. With new levels come new power-ups or the means to improve your high scores, and then the cycle beings anew. The fact the game generates a new world to try every day is another nice feature – each generated landscape sticks around long enough to give you a good amount of time to truly master it, but not long enough for things to get ever get stale. None of these ideas are mind-blowing, I concur, but they’re enough to keep you coming back to the game once the appeal of high score chasing wears thin. With Steam Workshop additionally seeing people generate some truly crazy levels, the game’s lifespan extends far beyond when you’d probably initially expect. Things aren’t entirely perfect, mind you. Some of those aforementioned challenges the game throws up at you feel blatantly more difficult when compared to the rest, and a bunch of the rewards you’ll get for completing them are basically inferior compared to those that you unlocked many a level ago. While not frequent in the slightest, I’ve also had a few occasions where I’ve encountered a death which felt downright unfair  – either I’ve suddenly found myself flying at an impenetrable wall of stone, or power-ups don’t appear anywhere near the frequency you need them to in order to viably stay alive. The menus also achieve something remarkable in the sense they’re both very basic and oddly confusing – the ability to customise your ship’s wings is not advertised very well, for instance, and I’ve had moments where joypad button prompts kept popping up even though I was using a keyboard and mouse. The fact you can’t restart after dying if using a joypad (forcing you to reach over and do it with your mouse) is also something that may seem tiny, but becomes so incredibly frustrating over extended play it’s impossible to ignore.  The question that perhaps sprung into your mind at the start of this review, of course, is why you should be buying this game when I’ve highlighted there’s so many free alternatives online. It’s a fair enough question... But in response, I would state that Race the Sun does things so well, and implements its own ideas in a way that keeps you truly interested, that I honestly think it’s worth your time and money. I was pleasantly surprised by how much entertainment I got out of it, and I think you will be too. Just don’t go beating my scores.

content:
y 3
												For all the grand adventures and intricate experiences that video games have to offer nowadays, sometimes it’s the older and simpler ideas that stick in the mind the most. You may share similar memories to me; ones of heading to websites such as Miniclip, and playing those little games which consisted of dodging and weaving a spaceship round the many blocks and obstacles that came hurtling in your direction. It was good, clean fun. Well, Race the Sun doesn’t really try and disguise the fact that at its core it’s basically offering more of the same. Still, that’s not a bad thing – the concept remains fun even today, whether you are wearing the rose tinted glasses of nostalgia or not.  It continues to be satisfying to watch your score go up and up as you expertly weave your way through the narrowest of gaps, all the while experiencing that jolt in your stomach as you brush far too close to your death. Even when you inevitably turn into a fine mist, the feeling you can always do better compels you to hit that restart button and so through the whole process again. Race The Sun manages to easily pull all those emotions out of you, but goes on to amplify them via the added spice of challenging you to stay one step ahead of a setting sun, all via the means of collecting certain power –ups and staying out of the shadows. This makes it so you have to be taking more risks if you want to survive for any extended period of time, meaning those exciting near death moments come at such a rapid pace it certainly keeps the blood pumping. It’s a cool little mechanic.That’s not the only thing different that Race the Sun adds to the table, either. There’s also a list of challenges to complete, varying from reaching certain distances to performing a number of risky manoeuvres, where success slowly levels you up. With new levels come new power-ups or the means to improve your high scores, and then the cycle beings anew. The fact the game generates a new world to try every day is another nice feature – each generated landscape sticks around long enough to give you a good amount of time to truly master it, but not long enough for things to get ever get stale. None of these ideas are mind-blowing, I concur, but they’re enough to keep you coming back to the game once the appeal of high score chasing wears thin. With Steam Workshop additionally seeing people generate some truly crazy levels, the game’s lifespan extends far beyond when you’d probably initially expect. Things aren’t entirely perfect, mind you. Some of those aforementioned challenges the game throws up at you feel blatantly more difficult when compared to the rest, and a bunch of the rewards you’ll get for completing them are basically inferior compared to those that you unlocked many a level ago. While not frequent in the slightest, I’ve also had a few occasions where I’ve encountered a death which felt downright unfair  – either I’ve suddenly found myself flying at an impenetrable wall of stone, or power-ups don’t appear anywhere near the frequency you need them to in order to viably stay alive. The menus also achieve something remarkable in the sense they’re both very basic and oddly confusing – the ability to customise your ship’s wings is not advertised very well, for instance, and I’ve had moments where joypad button prompts kept popping up even though I was using a keyboard and mouse. The fact you can’t restart after dying if using a joypad (forcing you to reach over and do it with your mouse) is also something that may seem tiny, but becomes so incredibly frustrating over extended play it’s impossible to ignore.  The question that perhaps sprung into your mind at the start of this review, of course, is why you should be buying this game when I’ve highlighted there’s so many free alternatives online. It’s a fair enough question... But in response, I would state that Race the Sun does things so well, and implements its own ideas in a way that keeps you truly interested, that I honestly think it’s worth your time and money. I was pleasantly surprised by how much entertainment I got out of it, and I think you will be too. Just don’t go beating my scores.

content:
ber 23, 2014
												As alluded to in the title, the goal of Race The Sun is to travel for as long as possible, using quick reflexes to avoid obstacles and shadows while increasing your score before the sun eventually sets. Along the way you'll need to pick up scattered energy bursts to help fend off the impending darkness, at which point your solar-powered ship will begin to slow down considerably before finally stopping all together. The racing itself feels very slick and there's a terrific sense of tension that hits once you advance beyond the first couple regions and reach some truly heinous areas. The blocky and minimalistic visual style is surprisingly good-looking in motion, thanks largely to some really nice lighting effects. There isn't a whole lot of variety to the soundtrack but what's there is still quite solid. New tracks are procedurally-generated every 24 hours, and the use of leaderboards help make high-score chasing a reason to keep coming back.The control scheme is very simplistic (analog stick to move, action button to jump when available) but I couldn't help but notice a slight yet noticeable amount of lag while playing that is directly tied to v-sync. There's no in-game option to turn it off, but I was able to force it off using RadeonPro for my AMD card. Being limited to a single track each day can also make runs a bit repetitive, a feeling that's enhanced by the limited soundtrack and oft-repeated backgrounds. Thankfully there is Steam Workshop integration so that players can create their own tracks for others to enjoy.(EDIT: In regards to runs becoming repetitive - After playing a bit more, I now feel like it isn't as big a concern as I initially thought. Each track/region is loaded with branching paths in addition to portals that temporarily take you to bizarre alternate regions. This helps make each run feel a little more unique if you to decide to mix it up and take different routes each time.)Despite a couple small issues, Race The Sun is a beautiful and simple yet thrilling endless runner. Runs may only last for a few minutes at a time, but it makes for some exciting bursts of racing that will test your concentration and timing.

												This is a very respectable little diversion, especially for the wonderful price of free. It's sort of a procedurally generated Wipeout where you just fly forwards as fast as you can, picking up power-ups and trying to get to the end of the level without crashing into stuff. It's very stylized, and the sunset conceit gives it a memorable look. Much like Wipeout, the mechanics are essentially based on a trial-and-error process of learning the optimal paths through the level, but by recreating those levels every 24 hours it theoretically remains interesting. Honestly, i played it for a day and then never went back because i don't find the repetitive-death mechanic very compelling, but for an hour or two it was entertaining and pretty.

												Man, what an engaging game. It doesn't do much, but it's great at what it does. If you like adrenaline-fueled arcade racing then this might be the game for you. But when I say racing, you aren't really racing oponents - as the name says you are racing the sun. You weave through obstacles at high speed in a solar-powered ship with only limited batteries, and the sun is sinking ever closer to the horizon. How far can you make it before the sun sets?I really enjoy the way the maps work. Each day at a set time the world gets reset; a new set of procedurally generated stages are laid out and are used by everybody for the next 24 hours, with daily leaderboards as well as tracking of all-time high scores.Surpisingly it isn't terrible to play on a keyboard, but a controller is STRONGLY recommended.

content:
31, 2016
												To hear our full review of Race the Sun, listen to the episode on Game Hoard Podcast[soundcloud.com]Race the Sun is a fun, simple, endless runner where you pilot a solar-powered hovercraft. You have to dodge obstacles while collecting power ups and keeping pace with the sun so as to maintain power. Besides trying to rise in the leaderboards, there are objectives to complete (such as making it to a certain distance, spending an amount of time airborne, doing a bunch of barrel rolls without crashing, etc.) that keep the game interesting. Beating these objectives levels you up and lets you get new power ups and upgrades. Additionally, the developers upload a new level every 24 hours, so there is always a new challenge. The game also includes a fairly robust level editor that allows users to create and share their own levels. Some of these levels can be accessed by portals found within the developer levels.All of this leads to an experience that is engaging, challenging, and very rewarding, despite a total lack of story and the very simple graphics and sound. Overall, we definitely recommend playing the game if you want an arcade type of experience that still offers new challenges after many hours of play.

content:
er 14, 2014
												        First off, think of Race The Sun as a mobile game, but magnified onto a larger screen. There is no story, no dialogue: just the simple objective of don't die. That includes getting as far as you can while the sun is still up, as you are a solar powered aircraft (hence the title, Race the Sun). So pretty much it's a time trial, except instead of numbers on a timer, it's a natural time limit. Controls are intuitive and simple, like many other platformers. As you progress in the game you'll get more abilites and things to collect while dodging huge rotating boxes and manoeuvring through narrow tunnels. There is also a level designer, although that was too complex for me to figure out how to use, and I decided just racing would be a better use of my time.         Overall, this is a fun, action packed platformer with beautiful minimalist graphics that brings a new dynamic of racing the Sun until it sets. Highly recommended, but not for its price. I bought it for $2 while it was on sale, and for that it is more than worth it. However, $10 might be a little on the pricey side for a game with its amount of content.          Regardless of the price, I rate it 8/10 for what it is.

content:
, 2014
												I purchased this game not long ago during a sale, and on a whim. I'm not a huge arcade game fan, nor have I ever spent any decent amount of time in any "flying racing" game. What attracted me to this was its simplistic design. It's an absolutely beautiful game even though it took about a minute to download in full (seriously!). I also thought it was an original idea, and the procedural world thing also pulled at me.So, despite never having been a fan of this type of game in the past, I have to say, I'm loving this. The music is top notch, the worlds are beautiful and change daily, and it truly makes you feel like you're on a mission (a mission to what? RACE THE SUN! **Crickets**). I picked this game out of my Steam backlog because I felt like something simple and relaxing, and oddly enough, this game does that for me. This game is what you allow it to be, really. You can play it just to waste time and relax, or you can try beating your top scores and accomplishing certain tasks the game consistently updates for you to do that help you level (much like the awesometacular game Jetpack Joyride for the PS Vita does).Race the Sun has a seriously high "just one more level" aspect, and the way it presents itself in terms of leveling, tasks to do, etc., open it up for a wider audience than just the "arcade racing" crowd. 90% of the time, I don't want to feel stressed or on edge when I'm gaming, which is what most arcade games do to me. In Race the Sun, I'm not on edge, because even if I have a run that sucks, I still have fun, can laugh at my mistakes, and may even accomplish some progress on my level.On a final note, there is massive replay value here. The game worlds change daily, and it allows you to even mess with its editor to create content for yourself. You can also customize your ship and unlock upgrades, which will take a while to get all of. I highly recommend this game to those who already like the genres it inhabits, but also to those looking for a great game that is fun to jump in and out of, to relax or challenge yourself. Race the Sun is a great game, and gets everything it does right.

y 10, 2015
												I'm going to dissent. At the time of writing, 95% of reviewers have recommended this game. I won't.It is a minimalist racing game that tests the reflexes. It is well done within its context. It is hard to find fault in what is implemented.The issue is, well, what is implemented amounts to not-very-much. I played it a few times after buying it, and haven't touched it since nor had any inclination to. Once you've played it a few times then that's it, you've exhausted the variety of the game - there's nothing left to discover other than how far you can get into the game. You'll never uncover anything new in terms of the gameplay. You just might see a few more types of object to dodge.Sure, the layout of each level changes every 24 hours. Sure, some people have created quite a variety of levels in the workshop. However, it all boils down to the same very simple game - dodge until you die. It's really a mini-game and as such I can't recommend it as a £6.99 (or ~$10) purchase.

content:
ry 22, 2014
												Type of Game:3D Endless RunnerVersion Played:PC version through SteamSimilar Games:Temple Run, Bit.Trip Runner, and to a lesser degree Star Fox (in the graphics department)The Good:An immediately satisfying arcade experience that is very easy to pick-up and play at any timeProcedurally generated levels that are never the same layout each dayThere are also “themed” worlds which mix up the environment when progressing in the gameWide open racing area that gives the player the freedom to move wherever they would want, avoiding obstacles as they do so of courseHypnotically relaxing soundtrack and sound effects that support the overall aesthetic of the gamePlaying with a controller and headphones is quite a trance-like and serene experienceProgression is natural and during the earlier stages it helps introduce game mechanics that then eventually turn into cosmetic and power-up unlockablesWhile the game is relaxing in a Rez sort of way, it also presents quite a challenge in being able to “twitch” the ship out of the way of oncoming objectsLeader-boards are a welcome addition that will appeal to those high score achievers among usThe developers (Flippfly) do an excellent job updating the game and staying active within the Race The Sun community, which is always good to see for indie gamesThere is also a level editor, which adds to the replay-ability of the titleThe Bad:The explosion animations and physics are rudimentary and considering how often the player sees them it feels like they could have been more robust and interestingSeeing the ship break into pieces and spread across the level would have appealed to the spectacle driven gamersReplay-ability will be an issue in the long run for Race The Sun, as is common with most arcade “pick up and play” style gamesThe level editor definitely helps in this departmentCan you play it while the children are awake?:You sure can. The graphics are very Starfox-esque and the content is mild. The could even be a game that they would enjoy playing with you, though there is no multiplayer outside of the leader-boards.Did I make time to complete it?:An endless runner really doesn’t end and that is the point. I enjoyed playing it for short bursts and imagine I will continue to do so during the times when I’m taking a break from a larger experience.Recommended Purchase Price:The game is a blast and can be enjoyed by anyone. Flying your ship down a vast and infinite world is exciting and fun. The fact that the worlds change every day is a huge bonus and the progression system keeps you coming back to play “one more round”. Though the game may lose your interest down the road, the content and design are well worth the asking price. The developers will be a team to watch going forward, as well:$9.99or100% of current retail value of $9.99http://www.gamersglance.comA Quick Look at Those Games You Might Buy

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
y 26, 2014
												In Race The Sun, you fly a solar powered hovercraft through an obstacle course, while the sun descends the sky. Your goal is to stay alive as long as possible to earn a high score. The course is divided into regions, which start off fairly relaxed as you fly through wide open spaces and around static objects, but gets progressively more intense as you squeeze through narrow gaps and make split second reactions to avoid moving objects. The race ends either when you crash, or run out of sunlight.Along the way you can collect various pickups. Blues increase your score, greens let you jump over obstacles, yellows give a speed boost and increase remaining sun time and purples allow you to respawn one time after a crash.During a race you can also work towards completing challenges such as collecting x number of pickups or earning a specific score. Every few challenges completed will grant you a level up and unlock a new pickup, or an item to equip on your craft. These items grant useful abilities, for example, the magnet will attract nearby pickups, and the jump storage lets you carry two jump pickups instead of one. But you have limited item slots, so your choice can influence your playing style. The map is procedurally generated every 24 hours, which means success depends more on skill than memorising the map. It also helps to keep the game fresh. Graphics are minimal, but that's actually a good thing. When you're flying at such high speeds, more detail would be distracting. Controls work well with either keyboard or 360 pad. I haven't noticed any bugs or crashes.Race The Sun is a simple concept with excellent execution, and it can be really fun when played in short sessions. I currently have logged 78 hours on Audiosurf and 29 hours on Aaaaa playing half an hour at a time, and I can see myself doing similar with Race The Sun.I definitely recommend checking this game out, and with such a low purchase price, there's no need to wait for a sale.

content:
2014
												What you are trying to accomplish in this game is simple: Just go as long and as far as you can, without crashing or running out of energy, both get increasingly harder as the Game progresses. You can keep going on battery for a short time, but you are basically a solar powered glider racing towards the sun. The longer you go the deeper the sun will sink, shadows of obstacles will grow longer and harder to avoid, which will slow you down or even stop you, all while obstacles get more plentiful and trickier to navigate around as the game progresses.One of it's main features is that the scoreboard and the map are reset every 24/h, which keeps it fresh and it's a great way of making exploiting kind of pointless. The leveling system is kind of interesting, but very linear and one-dimensional.Overall it's a stylish little game. It's great fun and optimal to pull out for 5 minutes every now and then.

												Race the Sun is a minimalist endless runner where you fly a solar powered ship towards the sun until you crash or the sun sets. You have challenges and level up in much the same way as other popular endless runners (e.g. Jetpack Joyride), but there are no microtransactions or ads in this PC game. It's a lot of fun, and addictive, kind of reminiscent of the original Star Fox in visuals. The game lacks polish in several noticeable areas (one of them being that my score usually doesn't get added to the leaderboard).

content:
er 31, 2015
												I don't normally care for runner games unless they do something to keep me invested. A lot of them now have levels to earn and missions to do and unlocks to... unlock, and Race the Sun is no different. But even after unlocking everything, I still go back to it now and then because of how solid the basic gameplay is.You're the pilot of a solar-powered hovercraft, speeding towards the setting sun in an attempt to stay in daylight. Shadows cast by mountains, structures, and clouds will all slow you down, and when the sun sets, you're done. To keep up with the sun you'll need to dodge the many obstacles in your wide-open path, as well as pick up booster items to thrust you forward at even higher speed. I wasn't kidding about speeding towards the sun, because even your regular pace feels like hundreds of miles per hour. Dodging obstacles and steering into pickups is thrilling and harrowing, and pulling off tight maneuvers is always satisfying.There are all manner of items to pick up across the levels like point multipliers, jumps, shields, and more. Completing tasks like clearing 3 levels without bumping anything or jumping 5 times earns you XP towards new ranks, which unlock upgrades and decals for your ship. There are 25 ranks to earn, giving you a goal for at least a few hours. Even beyond that there are reasons to keep flying, though. The main levels change every day, giving you new layouts to tackle. There's also a hard mode and a maze mode to unlock, and user-created levels to try, including one user-created level hidden in the regular game each day!The presentation is a unique blend of stark, clean visuals, soothing soundtrack, and a strangely casual tone to the text. All the elements are there for a game that you can load up for 5 or 10 minutes for a quick run, or turn on for an hour and work at, or start the free-flight mode and just chill. There's no fighting so it won't properly scratch that Starfox itch you might get from the screenshots, but it's well worth a few hours of your time to explore and enjoy.

												This game is a four letter word, namely ♥♥♥♥!or maybe a divine word and a four letter word, such as HOLY ♥♥♥♥!In otherwords.....  this game is simply amazing.  It also might give you a heart attack, or make you feel all giggity on the inside, butterflies in the stomach and such.  That's the effect I'm getting right now; something between that and the heart-pounding fight or flight adrenaline rush of a century (a lil hyperbole there).You fly in the smoothest riding, touchiest to control aircraft in the universe cruising at lightning speed.  Every crash brings both a sense of dread and elation!  After awhile, crashing becomes insanely fun, actually!  In this game, unlike sex, lasting 3 minutes is a good thing!  What feels even more good than the ejaculatory experience of exploding into objects with your 'aircraft' is the experience of weaving impossibly through obstacles, or richocheting off of them to extreme heights only to be thrown down into a chaotically destructive maze of impossibility.  BUY THIS ♥♥♥♥.  It's also similar to Super Hexagon and I thought it would be useful to compare the two, since I am so in love with that game as well, so.....THE BREAKDOWN:  (Comparison of Race the Sun and Super Hexagon)On the annoying scale: I would rank it slightly under SuperHexagon which is a game that should also be in your library if you end up being into this game, or if you haven't already bought it.... SH, as it stands is the most annoying/frustrating game of all time.  RtS: 8 , SH: 10Challenge/Difficulty:  I would have to say about the same thing here, but it's a close match.  RtS: 9, SH: 10Fun Factor:  BOTH 10's!Visual Appeal:  This is where Race the Sun takes the lead, with a score that is relative to this type of very minimalist arcade game:  RtS: 10, SH: 8Music Annoyingness: 10 - 10Mind-♥♥♥♥ing Awesomeness:  10-10

er 13, 2013
												Highly addictive, This game will have you saying, "Just one more try!..." Fly your way through regions filled with obstacles and buildings as you race against the sun in your solar powered... uh, hover plane I guess I'll call it. Pick up powerups that reverse the sun and offer you more time to fly, cause when the sun does finally set, It's game over.(Funny how they have the technology to build a solar panel ship, but not a battery for night, lol) Leveling up will unlock more add-ons for your ship, like magnets that make pickups easier to grab, jump storage that offers an extra jump you can hold on to and lots more as you level up. Controller friendly options also offer a more suitable playing experience for some users although you can use the keyboard too, I found the contoller to be more suitable to my liking. There are also leaderboards so be prepared to challenge your friends for Highscores! I'm battling my friends already. Great game to pass the time and easy to learn, I will reccomend this game to any gamer out there that enjoys a good challenge!

												Race The Sun is a perfect example of why, I love Steam so much.  This is a gem I never would have noticed if it wasn't for the Steam sale.  The game has excellent controls and great music as well.  The graphics are nice and minimal and flying feels fluid and natural.  For 2.99 this game is an absolute steal.  Games like this renew my faith in games in general.  I applaud the developers of this game.  Everyone should check Race The Sun out. Just understand that there is no story or anything like that. By all means give this game a shot you won't be dissapointed.
