content:
, 2014
												This game reminds me of 3D death chase on the ZX-Spectrum. However, as none of you are old enough to remember than I best elaborate. This game is a basically a racing / dodging game, you are trying to race the sun in your solar power vehicle. The sun is setting in the distance, casting shadows on the scenery in your way. The lower the sun, the longer the shadows, and whilst your vehicle is powered by the sun, entering the shadows = slower speed. This itself might be an advantage as the game runs along at a hell of a pace and thou' early levels you will dodgy the scenery with ease, later levels it gets MUCH more difficult. If the sun sets, it's game over, if you hit the scenery (most likely) its game over. Along the way there are power ups to collect, some increase your score multiplier, some buy you a bit more time, some offer you a shield, some offer a jump facility (usually good for getting out of trouble). The maps are randomly generated, there are "objectives" that help you raise the level of your craft which gives you various additional perks. The genius of this game is the maps are randomly generated every 24 hours!. So today's level/game is nothing like yesterdays and wont be the same tomorrow.   The random maps are the same for everybody (if that makes sense, so yes the map is random, but someone playing on the same day as you has the same level). There is a learning curve; however, with repeated attempts you do get better and progress. It's good for a quick blast. A 20 minute filler game, which is different everytime you play it (so long as you play it on different days) :D

content:
20, 2014
												Easy to learn, hard to master... just how a game should be.The courses change every day, giving you a new and interesting problem to solve every day.  I take a small dose of this game with breakfast.  Its controls are simple... so much so that it can played with one hand, leaving your other to shove your breakfast burrito into your face.  But don't let that fool you.  RTS is a game that demands your attention and reflexes, but with great reward.Not very graphically intense, but it's better this way.  Your objective is simple, your controls are simple, and your environment should match, especially given that this is a a fast reflex and short-term planning game.  Complexity would only create more problems in the way of hitbox management and identification.  Immersion, as a result, is minimal yet engaging.Progression can be a bit slow through the ship levels, but if you focus, you can achieve even some of the goals that seem more difficult than the others, resulting in a bigger jump through the leveling process.And then... the unlocked mode.  I won't spoil it, but... Yeah.  Awesome.+1.  Time is running out.

content:
er 29, 2013
Race The Sun is awesome.I originally bought this game on a whim, during one of the numerous Steam sales. It looked like a great concept, new and original, and that really appealed to me.I really love how this game can be so versatile. It can be a casual 5-minute game, or a highly competitive hierarchy of hundreds of players scrambling over each other to be the one at the top.Being a relatively new game, the leaderboards are free of the burden of hackers (or the ten digit score numbers that point towards one), but that also means that the game has multiple bugs.Lighting is the one that stands out to me. The game is based around a craft speeding towards the setting sun in a desperate and inevitably vain attempt to escape the oncoming darkness and the oblivion coming with it. You have to stay out of the shadows cast by obstacles, or your solar energy will deplete and you will slow down. This usually has no problem, but I've noticed that when passing by multiple obstacles in quick sucession (Like if you have a x26 multiplier), the shadows (or at least, their affect on your batteries) seem to trip up and not work sometimes.However, like I said, this is a very new game, and these types of things are to be expected. In fact, I've been pleasently surprised by the lack of bugs and glitches, and the amount of patches and fixes.Lighting is a very tricky thing to manage, though, especially while keeping FPS in mind, and I don't mind it at all.Overall, out of ten, I give this game a nine.That's a 9/10, or an A-, if this were a test.To be fair, I almost never give out anything above.So what are you waiting for? Steal Borrow your parent's wallet, and run down to the confusing bazaar of games that is the Steam Store, and buy a copy for yourselves!You won't regret it!

er 10, 2013
												Race The Sun boils every racing game down to the core game play mechanic: move fast and avoid stuff. In this game, you move very fast, and try hard to avoid what can only really be described as "stuff". Despite its unique aspects, this game sits in a familiar groove.It shouldn't be called Race the Sun, it should be called Chase the Sun, and it shouldn't be called that, it should be called Chase Your Old Record, because the titular Sun is nothing but a countdown timer. This source of mild frustration of a Sun gradually sets over the horizon, and since your birdplanewhatsit is solar powered, this is not something you want. However, the Sun will set, and your fun will grind to a halt, giving you just enough time to consider the merits of some kind of battery before you're back to round 1 again. There are yellow glassy starry somethings that you can pick up (smash into) which put a bit of time back on the clock, but not much.Still, it's a fun game. There's a level-up system based on achievements, which unlock modifications and power-ups. These let you Chase Your Old Record for a little longer. Ignore the videos and screenshots, they misrepresent the game. Chase Your Old Record is not pretty by design, it's very stark and monochromatic. You'll spend no time looking at those interesting shapes as they whizz by, and nothing will surprise you after about half an hour. Get out your controller (keyboard sucks for this game), put on your headphones, slip into the zone, and spend some time travelling blindingly fast.

content:
7, 2014
												Race The Sun is a fast-paced racing game. You contol a solar powered speeder, attempting to stay in the sun so you can keep blazing through a minimalistic world, gaining points over time as long as you stay alive. Unfortunately, the sun is still setting even as you are shooting above the ground, so you have to pick up yellow boost powerups that temporarily cause your speeder to go REALLY fast, so fast that the sun raises in the sky as you are going faster than it is setting. There are blue triangles scattered across the level that give you points, and getting five of them multiplies the passive point gains you get.The level you play in are separated into regions, each region giving you harder and harder obstacles. The level is procedurally generated every 24 hours, being consistent for all players for that day.Hitting a wall kills you, and the run is over. If the sun sets, or you simply sit in the shadows too long, you will lose power. This isn't an instant loss, but without power the craft starts slowing down, eventually coming to a stop if you can't get sunlight fast enough. When you do come to a stop, the run is over and you have to try again.There are little tasks that the game gives you to do. There are easy, medium, and hard tasks. Completing the tasks will give you experience that goes towards leveling up, leveling up unlocks more features. Easy tasks give one experience point, medium tasks give two, and hard tasks give three. Please note: the multiplier and boost are only available after you unlock them, but it's only level 2-3, which is simple to get. There are also a ton of more fun features you unlock as you level up, like power ups, and ship decals.You can't beat the game, you just go as long as you can, getting as many points as you can. There are leaderboards that reset each day as the level is regenerated, so you can compete with your friends, and the world.Overall, I thoroughly enjoy this game, and I hope you get it.Unless you don't like these kind of games, I completely understand.

content:
ber 3, 2015
												Race the Sun is a Endless Runner type Indie game. It is Fast paced and gets Faster as the game goes on the goal is to Race The Sun and not Die, you can do this by picking up yellow "Boosters" to reverse the setting of the sun for a small moment, go through "Portals" to skip the current region, You can Pick up "Jump" powerups to jump over obstacle in your way (you can do this by pressing Space by default) and also by picking up shield powerups to give you a "Shield" for when you hit an obstacle.This is also a Leaderboard based game so you score by just racing, but you increase your multiplier by picking up "Tris" every 5 Tris ups your multplier by 1x.You also have mini objective to complete and in doing so you get either 1/2/3 Points after a set about of points you unlock stuff like powerups to equip on your ship there is stuff like "Magnet" to increase your pickup range of tris and powerups, and "Jump Storage" so you can hold more than 1 Jump at a time, and there is also decals you can put on your wins (you unlock the left wing decals first then later the Right wing decals).There is also an apocalypse gamemode you unlock I haven't played much of it but it is a lot crazier than the normal game modeMy over all rating for this game is 8.5/10It does start off slow, it can be a tiny bit annoying at times (but that's just me)but over all it is verry verry fun and I play it 10+ times almost every day

content:
20, 2014
												Easy to learn, hard to master... just how a game should be.The courses change every day, giving you a new and interesting problem to solve every day.  I take a small dose of this game with breakfast.  Its controls are simple... so much so that it can played with one hand, leaving your other to shove your breakfast burrito into your face.  But don't let that fool you.  RTS is a game that demands your attention and reflexes, but with great reward.Not very graphically intense, but it's better this way.  Your objective is simple, your controls are simple, and your environment should match, especially given that this is a a fast reflex and short-term planning game.  Complexity would only create more problems in the way of hitbox management and identification.  Immersion, as a result, is minimal yet engaging.Progression can be a bit slow through the ship levels, but if you focus, you can achieve even some of the goals that seem more difficult than the others, resulting in a bigger jump through the leveling process.And then... the unlocked mode.  I won't spoil it, but... Yeah.  Awesome.+1.  Time is running out.

content:
er 29, 2013
Race The Sun is awesome.I originally bought this game on a whim, during one of the numerous Steam sales. It looked like a great concept, new and original, and that really appealed to me.I really love how this game can be so versatile. It can be a casual 5-minute game, or a highly competitive hierarchy of hundreds of players scrambling over each other to be the one at the top.Being a relatively new game, the leaderboards are free of the burden of hackers (or the ten digit score numbers that point towards one), but that also means that the game has multiple bugs.Lighting is the one that stands out to me. The game is based around a craft speeding towards the setting sun in a desperate and inevitably vain attempt to escape the oncoming darkness and the oblivion coming with it. You have to stay out of the shadows cast by obstacles, or your solar energy will deplete and you will slow down. This usually has no problem, but I've noticed that when passing by multiple obstacles in quick sucession (Like if you have a x26 multiplier), the shadows (or at least, their affect on your batteries) seem to trip up and not work sometimes.However, like I said, this is a very new game, and these types of things are to be expected. In fact, I've been pleasently surprised by the lack of bugs and glitches, and the amount of patches and fixes.Lighting is a very tricky thing to manage, though, especially while keeping FPS in mind, and I don't mind it at all.Overall, out of ten, I give this game a nine.That's a 9/10, or an A-, if this were a test.To be fair, I almost never give out anything above.So what are you waiting for? Steal Borrow your parent's wallet, and run down to the confusing bazaar of games that is the Steam Store, and buy a copy for yourselves!You won't regret it!

content:
r 9, 2015
Received free copy.TL;DR: I recommend this game but only on sale, there's just not enough here to be worth $9.99 plus $1.99 for DLC that really should've been part of the base game.[Difficulty - average]: It can be easy or hard depending on your ship configuration, memorizing abilty and reflexes.[Controls - good]: You have turn left, turn right, and use special ability... pretty simple to understand.[Music - good]: It's not too distracting but manages to create an atmosphere that fits with racing a setting sun. Or you can just turn it off and use your own music of choice which is always a plus for games.[Graphics - good]: It's simple and smooth which is a plus when reflexes are important to playing at high speeds and any framerate drop or stuttering could spell death. I hate graphic dependant games since they're too much for my older computer, luckily there's no issue at all with this game so just about anyone can play it.[Content - average]: As I said at the top, there isn't much to do in this game and that's mainly because it's all hidden behind unlock requirements which can take awhile to actually unlock. You can only have one ship attachment at the beginning and I have no idea how long it takes to actually get to the point where you can have multiple ones equipped. I'm still at the point where I have 2 choices for levels, the base mode that has a set level that changes every 24 hours or Apocalypse mode which is the base mode with more explosions. Credits mode doesn't count because you can literally afk while doing it because all you do is fly straight and wait for it to end. (Why they didn't have you interact with them by having you dodge falling credits seems like a huge waste). It does have a map editor which adds some feeling of community to it but again you have no choices for level selection beyond what is randomly generated each day.Then you have the Sunrise DLC which is a freestyle zen mode from what I understand of the description. (Why on earth that wasn't included in the basic game which was already lacking in stuff to do is also beyond me).[Overall - good]: Despite the complaints I have for the content, this game is a good time-killer. The built-in games a computer OS comes with (think Solitaire, Minesweeper, or Pinball) are probably the most played games just because you don't always have the time or motivation to commit to a whole game that could take hours to complete.  This game fits into that category of games very well. However it is simply not worth the $12 price tag for it and the Sunrise DLC, between $5 and $8 is closer to what this game should be at.

content:

												This game is really great. It has a very simple design and concept but is very satisfying to play. It's easy to jump in and play for a shot time but can be very difficult. You pilot a solar glider over an abstract landscape toward the sun, You need to avoid the various obstacles and you need to avoid shadows, otherwise you glider will eventually lose power. Get through each area before the sun sets or it's "game over." Collecting blue pyramids increases your multiplier to increase the points you get for the distance you travel without crashing and dying, or bumping into obstacles, which decrements your multiplier. The game really gives you a sense of speed and you can get to feeling like the obstacles are starting to box you in, which creates a nice tension at times. I saw this game on the Steam Store and thought it looked interesting, but it wasn't until the devs made the game free for a day that I grabbed it. I am glad I did. I ended up buying the DLC to support the devs. Good move, devs!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 16, 2016
												Race the Sun is a simple concept with a surprising amount of depth.  This game could have been a straight forward survival game were all you had to do was dodge objects and see how long you could survive.  Instead the developers added an excellent mission system to challenge the player to explore and try new things.  The natural growth of your skills combined with a thoughtful quest system makes this a very rewarding experience.The title says it all in this game.  As you fly towards the sun you must avoid the different objects lie in your way.  The father you go the more difficult this becomes; columns with fall over to block your path, balls will rolls into your way, and at times you'll be bottle necked into a tight space.  Not only that but you must keep in the sun light to power your glider.  The sun will slow fall on its own but if you stay in the shade of the objects for too long your battery will start to die and sun will fall much faster than normal.  You'll be motivated to explore to collect Tris to gradually increase your multiplier which is necessary for getting a high-score.Thankfully, you have power-ups and attachments that will help on your journey.  A yellow boost will both increase your speed while simultaneously raising the sun.  The green power-up lets you jump over obstacles were as the purple power-up shields you from a fatal collision.  Over time you'll unlock and level up attachments, some of which let you hold onto multiple power-ups.  Other attachments let you survive longer in the shadows or increase your ability to turn your ship faster.The attachments along with other perks are unlock though the mission system.  At all times there are three tiers of progressively challenging missions.  The first tier is usually so easy its just a matter of time before completing the quest.  The other two tier offers more challenging tasks you'll have to go out of your way for.  These goals range from doing multiple double jumps, flying through multiple zones with no collisions, or building up a really big multiplier.  When you complete a quest you get experience points based on how difficult the challenge is.  Build up enough experience to level up and receive a reward for your hard work.You really feel a wonderful sense of progression playing this game.  Overtime you'll get used to certain obstacles and become more confident with the super tight controls.  Everyday offers a new procedurally generated level.  As soon as you begin to memorize and master one world the next day offers a different layout.  This is great mechanic that keeps the players on their toes while making for an excellent competitive game where you can compete with friends on a daily basis.  For everything this game offers it does a superb job.  Anyone looking for a fun game they can really sink their teeth into I highly recommend Race the Sun.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
5, 2015
												To my surprise I ended up playing this game much more than I first thought. I liked the graphics, they were simple enough to make them not interfere with gameplay. Maybe they could've been a bit more varied with changing colors but not sure if that would've made any difference.To me this reminded of Hotline Miami. Not because of similarity in visuals, but the gameplay: fast, nerve-wracking, lots of deaths and repeats.The games difficulty was very well executed and I for myself found the game manageable. I lost the learning curve at 18 level mark, and then though I cannot get further without grinding lvl 1 challenges which were becoming intensly more dull and longer(Do something 6 times, do something X times).I enjoyed playing this game but thought it lacked many things that could've made it a real deal. The soundtrack of the game is non-existent, only one song which is pretty dull in the end. It works fine as it is, but for this kind of game, I think the game needs an excellent soundtrack to make me want to try it all over again.Also the game could've used some more meat over it's bones. I felt that once you got through the first level, it only becomes more difficult but nothing really changes. Essentially you see most of the games in your first few runs apart from some of the boosters which really are the dullest one can invent. More game modes could've made it more fun with better soundtracks, like endless-mode or something where the sun isn't actually. I know it's the main theme, but allowing one to try just avoiding the increasing amount of objects, without losing speed, could've made me play a few hours more.Also instead of upgrades, I thought this game could've used more boosters, tris and more ships. I think the liberal spreading of boosters and tris would've made the early levels more interesting because one would actively pursue different routes instead of just avoiding stuff. Now the first 3-4 levels can be occasionally be too easy to just surf through without getting anything. Tris are too sparse so if the levels are not scouted properly(previous tries), one has barely a chance to get more than 20 of them per level, decreasing with difficulty. Also since the speed of the craft is so fast, one barely can pursue those that are in the extremes of ones vision unless one knows they are there. More than dozen times I saw something, tried to turn the craft to left or right and just couldn't reach the thing I was trying to get. How disappointing.I think the game relies too much on the fact that player must play same level maybe 10-20 times so that he knows where everything is, yet makes little effort to make it actually enjoyable. Here comes the music part again, that was so well done in Hotline Miami and FTL.All in all this is a fun game and I would recommend this for a try, but I cannot say this will be a great game for everyone. Most might find it dull after few tries. For some it's a game of endless tries and thrills. For me it was a game that lasted few hours but that made me want more. Maybe I'll look into the sequal if it ever comes out.

, 2014

content:
ry 16, 2016
												Race the Sun is a simple concept with a surprising amount of depth.  This game could have been a straight forward survival game were all you had to do was dodge objects and see how long you could survive.  Instead the developers added an excellent mission system to challenge the player to explore and try new things.  The natural growth of your skills combined with a thoughtful quest system makes this a very rewarding experience.The title says it all in this game.  As you fly towards the sun you must avoid the different objects lie in your way.  The father you go the more difficult this becomes; columns with fall over to block your path, balls will rolls into your way, and at times you'll be bottle necked into a tight space.  Not only that but you must keep in the sun light to power your glider.  The sun will slow fall on its own but if you stay in the shade of the objects for too long your battery will start to die and sun will fall much faster than normal.  You'll be motivated to explore to collect Tris to gradually increase your multiplier which is necessary for getting a high-score.Thankfully, you have power-ups and attachments that will help on your journey.  A yellow boost will both increase your speed while simultaneously raising the sun.  The green power-up lets you jump over obstacles were as the purple power-up shields you from a fatal collision.  Over time you'll unlock and level up attachments, some of which let you hold onto multiple power-ups.  Other attachments let you survive longer in the shadows or increase your ability to turn your ship faster.The attachments along with other perks are unlock though the mission system.  At all times there are three tiers of progressively challenging missions.  The first tier is usually so easy its just a matter of time before completing the quest.  The other two tier offers more challenging tasks you'll have to go out of your way for.  These goals range from doing multiple double jumps, flying through multiple zones with no collisions, or building up a really big multiplier.  When you complete a quest you get experience points based on how difficult the challenge is.  Build up enough experience to level up and receive a reward for your hard work.You really feel a wonderful sense of progression playing this game.  Overtime you'll get used to certain obstacles and become more confident with the super tight controls.  Everyday offers a new procedurally generated level.  As soon as you begin to memorize and master one world the next day offers a different layout.  This is great mechanic that keeps the players on their toes while making for an excellent competitive game where you can compete with friends on a daily basis.  For everything this game offers it does a superb job.  Anyone looking for a fun game they can really sink their teeth into I highly recommend Race the Sun.

content:
y 1, 2014
												Tot's Rundown: Don't buy this game expecting to play it for hours in one sitting, or a lot of depth. Buy it for an easy-going experience that will keep you coming back day after day.Race The Sun is a simple game at heart, and as such I just don't think it's realistic to expect to get hours of gameplay out of it in one sitting. I don't think that's what the game sets out to do, either. What it does do wonderfully is provide a great pick-up-and-play title that can easily become a daily routine.Watch the trailer or some other videos of it, and you'll get the basic premise. Yep, you just dodge stuff. There is no throttle and there is no brake, you're simply flying as fast and as far as you can before the sun - your source of energy - sets on the horizon. There are various pickups which make the gameplay more varied as you progress, such as an essential item that makes the sun rise in the sky for that much needed extended time. It's almost reminiscent of an old arcade-style racer, where when you ran out of time you had to insert more quarters, only without the quarters.The key aspect of this game is the changing worlds. Every day they release a new world for you to race in, so the challenge won't be the same as the last time you played it. And each world, at that, can be pleasantly varied as you fly farther and farther, progressing through the world's "stages." Add in custom user-made worlds (the game comes with a world editor) and Steam Workshop integration incoming, and you've got a whole lot of replayability.

												I see some people are having a tough time choosing if to buy this game or not so i will go over the pros and the cons.Pros-fastpaced-both casual players and hardcore players can play-world resets-the addition of the workshopCons-can get repetitive-leveling is difficult when higher than about 10-a lot of repetition-tedious for some of the challengesSo with these pros and cons that I thought of, You can decide for yourself or if you want my opionion on this game it is, this game will make you want to punch you computer screen once you play for long periods of time, you will not only see a ton of repetition if you go down the same path (remember you can go either way), and last i would only tell you to buy this if you dont get mad easily. So I say yes to most but to some I would have to say no, but you can never tell what side you are on till you try the game-First- Find out what time the world resets for you (i.e. My world resets at 10pm) once you have found out the time minus 2 hours and add 2 hours from that number. (i.e. My case it would be 8pm and 12am)-Second- Play the game only during these time zones. (One note since the world resets during this time don't try for challenges it might get difficult)This is how i can play this game for a long period of time without wanting to punch my computer screen. I do recommend this tip for anyone who doesn't like to play the game for more than 2 hours because of repetition.

content:
er 25, 2013
												Race the Sun reminds me in many ways of the Java-based title flood runner -- another endless runner that would see you piloting a hovercraft of sorts through procedurally generated terrain, populated by increasingly dense simple shapes. flood runner was a game that proved so instantly accessible and absurdly addictive that our school at the time had to ban every site that carried it, just to make sure we did some work.Race the Sun also falls into that mould. Ostensibly an endless runner with two simple rules -- always move forward, and never crash -- players are free to roam about the minimalist landscapes in lateral fashion via a solar-powered vehicle. Indeed, you'll need to in order to avoid the rush of oncoming shapes and structures. The turning circle of your ship is sluggish to begin with, and decisive flying is of paramount importance.The game begins with languid sojourns through open, spacious environments, the sun atop the horizon constantly threatening to set and bring your journey to an end. There are pickups strewn liberally across the maps: blue ones (Tris) add to your score multiplier, green ones earn you the ability to make a single jump, the white ones enshrined in soft pillars of light prolong the day and speed up your craft, and then there's the rare pink object which gives you one free pass when it comes to the crunch.Diverting from the easy, straight course to risk ruin amidst the denser pockets of each level in order to chase down pickups seems needless at the very start But the first time the sun sets and leaves your craft without power, stranded ignobly and with a lamentable score, you begin to realise the importance of chasing them down.There's some progression in there too, with Jetpack Joyride-esque objectives in 1-star, 2-star, and 3-star difficulty flavourings, the completion of which will help to boost your pilot ranking. Some of these missions see you accumulating Tris or travelling a certain distance, others might have you performing a certain number of barrel rolls (thereby forcing you to move laterally a lot more than you would) within the space of a single run, or only turning left. There's a pleasant sense of accomplishment that follow the completion of some of these thingsOne of the best things about the whole experience is the relay system. If you're finding the game too tricky, you can make use of the little option at the end of each run that allows you to share a relay point via email or across social networks like Twitter and Facebook. Basically, another player can then start from where you finished, and then when they crash or run out of solar power, the chain can be continued. Buddy up with a friend, and you can leapfrog one another to maximise points and distance, helping to unlock more of the fiendish 3-star accomplishments. You can only create a four-stage relay, but it works very nicely indeed.So race the sun great game if you have a pc you need this even on the lowest graphical settings this game is a thrill to playAnother well deserved 10/10

content:
er 18, 2013
												Read the full review: http://www.cublikefoot.com/review/race-the-sun/I often found myself raging internally whilst playing Race the Sun. I'd get so far, just to crash right into a block that wasn't there a second ago. This only fueled my desire to try again, and again, and again, making this game fairly addictive.Race the Sun's objective is to simply "Race the Sun", as the title states. You're placed in control of what appears to be some sort of futuristic spaceship and tasked with riding towards the sun, just visible above the horizon directly ahead of the ship. The problem is, there are many obstacles in-between the ship and the sun. The obstacles become more obtrusive as time goes on, starting with the transition from static to dynamic objects. Upon crashing into any object, you're done, unless you happen to have a multiplier active, in which case, your multiplier disappears, but you remain alive.During this time, you're introduced to the various "challenges" that can be completed, and, upon completion, the challenge is replaced with a completely new challenge, among a variety of different challenges. These challenges reminded me of the goals included in that mobile game, Jetpack Joyride. The game also featured user-created worlds. Steam Workshop support is planned (according to the in-game menu), so we'll have to wait to unleash the full potential of the world builder.The game has a major flaw, that being the lack of diversity offered out of the box. Race the Sun is probably going to end up relying on user creations to keep its value over time, but the pre-packaged worlds did not satisfy the amount that I had expected from the game. Still looking forward to more worlds offered by the community.The game's graphics were set in grayscale, with a few very bright whites also present. This was a great style overall and I thought it fit well with the type of gameplay provided. The game also includes some great atmospheric sounds and music to it, although it was difficult to pay attention to while concentrating so hard on avoiding objects flying at you going hyperspeed.Race the Sun progressively built up my frustration when I played it for long periods of time. The gameplay works best when experienced in small bursts. Warning: Playing for extended periods of time may result in a broken controller. Race the Sun's purchase can be justified if you're the type of gamer who can't sit through a game for more than 30 minutes.

content:
2015
Race the Sun offers immersive, adrenaline packed experience; yet it's still the kind of game you can jump right into when you just have a few minutes to kill. Now that I think about it, I feel like that is a really rare combo to find in a game, at least for me it is...What is it about? / Gameplay   It's a pretty basic endless runner with an interesting twist. You are controlling an aircraft through obstacle-littered world at high velocity. Being solar-powered, shadows and sunset are your main concern. You must keep going fast enough to delay the inevitable end of your futile race for as long as possible…   The gameplay is very simplistic. Fly, dodge, jump, and collect stuff along the way. That's all I've been doing, because that's all there is to do in this game. Yet, strangely enough, I still find myself craving for more of the same…   The world you're flying through is divided into a regions, each being more difficult, due to rising ammount and variety of obstacles. The whole map is re-generated daily, offering a slightly different experience every day. I say slightly, because some elements always start to appear in the same regions, which I feel is fair. Anyway, the ever changing world keeps the game fresh, and if that's not enough for you, there are another two (unlockable) game modes and a level editor with Steam Workshop support.   The game sets various different challenges -  something like "collect XY points in one run" for example. Completing these challenges unlocks new ship upgrades, pick-ups and bunch of other stuff. There are also leaderboards and achievements to make your effort less pointless.Notes   I love how smooth, fluid and responsive the whole game feels. I haven't had a single problem with it. No lag, no framerate drops or bugs. In a fast-paced game, where blinking an eye can get you killed, I certainly do appreciate that.    The sense of speed in this game is insane. I have only played it for 4 hours as I'm writing this, but I know I will be coming back for more of that addictive, exhilarating and extremely immersive experience. I can only imagine how crazy it must be with Oculus Rift on your head. I'd be happy to try it, even if it meant ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ my pants (I'm dead serious here).   Also, generating new world every 24 hours is a brilliant move in a game like this. It gives you chance to get used to a new world and try your best in a leaderboard, while still keeping the game fresh and encouraging you to come back. Steam Workshop support is just a cherry on top. There's definitely a lot of replayability here.   The aesthetic is quite minimalistic, but it works and I like it. Also I'm sure it helps to avoid performance issues. There's no point in having complex, textured enviroments when moving at insane speed anyway… But like I said, I like it as it is. It gives the world this desolated-postapocalyptic-dystopian-wasteland-kind-of-feel. Soundtrack, although not very long, also helps with that representation. The individual tracks are pretty different in their atmosphere, but work very nicely together. Conclusion   If you're looking for a way to forget about the world around you for a while, test your reflexes and get your adrenaline and endorphine levels fixed in the process, this is the game you need. It's addictive, extremely rewarding and fun, with a great replay value. I labsolutely love it.   However, consider that this game is very minimalistic in it's design. I don't want to say it's lacking content, but I know some people may have trouble justifying the price tag because of it…so consider that, and maybe wait for a sale if that's what bothers you. Needless to say, I don't recommend it to people who don't like very fast-paced racing games / endless runners, or those who are not very good at making split-second decision.

Pick this up if you haven't already. ~PR0XIDIAN

content:
11, 2016
Product received for free
												I got this game when it was free for a day, but I will try to review it independent of this.This game is an endless runner, with the central core mechanic that you should, as the title suggests 'Race the Sun'. Your ship is powered by the sun, and when the sun sets, it's game over. You can pick up powerups to extend the time the sun is up for, to try and chase for a high score on the leaderboards. The game also has a challenge system where each run you are asked to complete certain objectives to gain stars. You also can make minor upgrades to your ship.When you die, it's game over, then you have to start from the beginning again the next game.The game is fairly good fun, and it certainly captures the frantic nature of racing at a high speed, seeing objects rush past makes the game quite tense and exciting. This fun is counteracted by the infuriation that collisions can provide. One wrong move can mean game over (or at least losing a life), and it's always a little annoying when you mess up a long way into a good run.The gameplay is pretty basic, just flying your ship along and dodging obstacles whilst picking up power ups. It reminds me a little of that old game 'cube runner' on iphone, in fact in many ways this game is a lot like a phone game, rather than a full pc game. Of course it almost goes without saying that there is no storyThe other thing is, the game only has so much time before it becomes boring. It's effectively the same every run (although the overall layout changes once per day, which is a nice feature), which means that unless you are good enough to get to the later stages, you'll be stuck going repeatedly through the early ones. This repetitiveness means that you can really only play the game for short bursts at a time before you've had enough, and (for me at least) feel ready to move onto a game with a bit more depth. This is a game that, in my opinion, just doesn't have the longevity to keep the player interested. Notice how even a lot of the positive reviews only have a few hours played.Overall the game is fun for a quick blast, but it is let down by it's repitive nature. I can't really recommend anyone to pay full retail price for it, but it was worth getting when it was free, and I think that if it sounds like you'd enjoy it, it would also be worth getting in a steam sale.I'm kind of torn on the rating, but I think I have to go negative because the game just isn't good enough to be good value for its full RRP, especially when you look at the quality of some of the other games you could pick up for a similar price. That said, it sounds like a lot of other people really liked it, so don't let me put you off.

r 6, 2015
												A non-biased Quick Look @ the game:


YouTube™ Video: ➜ A Quick Look @ 'Race The Sun' (GeForce GT 640, Windows 10) 

			Views: 13		

			This game is available here: http://store.steampowered.com/app/253030 SUPPPORT THIS CHANNEL ON PATREON: https://www.patreon.com/ParadiseDecay?ty=h (BONUS Steam Keys /Games & Music!) A non-biased...		

You are a solar craft. The sun is your death timer. Hurtle towards the sunset at breakneck speed in a futile race against time. Delay the inevitable by catching energy boosts which reverse the setting sun - if only for a moment. Race The Sun is inspired by arcade games of the past with a focus on highscores, short game sessions, and a sense of pure fun mingled with a nerve-wracking tension. The rules are simple: don't crash, stay in the light, and don't slow down! -  Recommended!

content:
ry 16, 2015
												You are a ship racing against a setting sun. Without solar power, your ship stalls and the game ends. This is a very fun game as other reviews attest to.I am more interested in the Lore of this game. Does RtS take place on Earth? Is this game a depiction of a future apocalypse? Is this the last sunset?  What are these strange geometries that you navigate? Are they the ruins of once great cities? Is your ship an ark carrying the last vestiges of humanity? Why is the ship compelled to race the sun, knowing that the sun can never be beaten. Existential. Sysiphean. Nihilistic. Protean. Mythopoetic. Lagubrious. These are all words I would (and am) use (-ing) to describe this game.Why do we race the sun? Because we want to stay in the light.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
r 31, 2015
												Race the Sun isn't bad, but it's not really getting me hot and bothered for endless runner action, either.I mean, I'm all for Kickstarted games that are seemingly like a '♥♥♥♥ you' to the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ gamer crowd, and Race the Sun's premise is just that: An endless runner game that feels like it should play on a phone, but has been released for the PC. (It did get ported to mobile devices later on, though.)The game is mostly solid, looks beautiful and clean, and controls pretty well. With the exception of the one user world I tried. I like how you can traverse to actual 'worlds' that other players have created while you're running through the game, but the one I tried was white on black and all the ground obstacles were white and hidden by the landscape, and I was irritated when I hit a white car while driving over a white foreground and died, because I couldn't ♥♥♥♥ing see what killed me! I pin the blame on the designer on that level, though.The game advertises a really neat co-op 'clan' premise where your friends can pick up after you've died in your game, but since I'm a Forever Alone and I think co-op is more gimmick than feature at this point, I didn't get the chance to try that out. There's not much going on in solo-play, other than 'endless running' and 'obligatory RPG mechanics' and 'RPG challenges with no choice to skip over the boring ones'. However, if you're here to chase scores and chew bubblegum, that gum is going to fall out of your mouth while you figure out the best path to get all the points so you can try in vain to beat the guy who hacked himself into the #1 spot on the leaderboards. Much like you're trying to beat the sun, you'll never beat the #1 guy on the leaderboards, because leaderboards in video games in 2015 are invitations for hackers to 'beat the system' and 'vote for Ron Paul'.So I don't feel much love or hate for Race the Sun. If you're looking for an endless runner, though, you could get this one?

content:

												A nice decent game. I got it for free, (which was great) and I'm pretty satisfied. It's a nice relaxing game game, with no clear objective or storyline. The plot is that you are a solar-powered craft flying and the sun, which powers your craft, is setting. You can collect energy boosts that, for a split second, stop the sun from setting. The endless concept is not something new (at all), but this game is. Good graphics and ambience, and it kind of reminds me of an iPad game I have called Forever Drive (https://itunes.apple.com/en/app/forever-drive/id442923846?mt=8) which had futuristic graphics with an endless concept AND a map editor- a perfect replica, only race-themed.So, conclusion: I'd recommend it, but not for it's full price. Get it in a bundle, or when it's on sale.

content:
, 2014
												Mixed feelings. I bought this game to enjoy some high-speed flying in an open world, but in farther regions of it I actually don't get that much enjoyment because of dense, hazardous, and unforgiving landscape that keeps me crashing into something. The landscape has patterns, of course, and those patterns can be more or less efficiently learned after several runs (thus allowing you to improve your performance), but even a slightest mistake imminently turns out to be fatal. The aircraft's ability to steer left and right does not really match its acceleration; sometimes I feel like I could use a bit more agility.The gameplay itself is relatively simple; if you watched videos on the game's page in Steam store, then you've actually seen most of what it has to offer.If you are happy to exercise your quick reaction and fast reflexes, then you will probably find this game involving and worthy of your money. If, otherwise, you are not the best in making correct decisions in milliseconds, then you might prefer to look for the fun somewhere else.

												Simple, addictive and challenging. Slick visuals, fitting audio and the controls are as close to perfect as they come. A new world and leaderboard is generated every 24 hours, keeping things fresh and interesting for frequent players. A fairly intuitive World Creator is included for making your own custom maps, which can then be shared with the community. Suitable for all ages and extremely easy to pick up and play for people just starting out. Very enjoyable, with plenty to offer for both casual and competitive gamers.

												I am beginning to enjoy games that make it  easy to have a quick 3-5 minutes of gametime but still reward you with a solid gaming experience. The games that do this best are games that have randomly generated daily challenges, (i.e Spelunky , The binding of Issac etc) and Race the Sun accomplishes this perfectly. If played for longer than 20 minutes at a time it can be infuriating , but making the daily challenge a part of my gaming routine is enough to keep my reflexes sharp and honed as this game is all about reaction time and quick decision making. Simple yet smart art style takes me back to my days of playing Star Wars in the arcade with the vector styled graphics.  Definitely a must for those that enjoyed games like F-zero or Wipe-out.

												A nice decent game. I got it for free, (which was great) and I'm pretty satisfied. It's a nice relaxing game game, with no clear objective or storyline. The plot is that you are a solar-powered craft flying and the sun, which powers your craft, is setting. You can collect energy boosts that, for a split second, stop the sun from setting. The endless concept is not something new (at all), but this game is. Good graphics and ambience, and it kind of reminds me of an iPad game I have called Forever Drive (https://itunes.apple.com/en/app/forever-drive/id442923846?mt=8) which had futuristic graphics with an endless concept AND a map editor- a perfect replica, only race-themed.So, conclusion: I'd recommend it, but not for it's full price. Get it in a bundle, or when it's on sale.

content:
2015
												Race The Sun is a good game, and you can probably tell whether you'll like it by the screenshots and videos on the Steam page, but, in case you're not sure, allow me to elaborate.I think the goal of the game is fairly obvious, you need to race the sun with a solar-powered spacecraft. The theme is not just a gimmick though: since some obstacles in the game project shadows, you will sometimes not be able to see the sun, and that will slow you down, meaning that the sun will set faster in the horizon. Basically, every mistake you make has an immediate and tangible effect on the game. The controls are tight and responsive, and the hitboxes seem logical and fair most of the time (if you die, it's most likely your fault and not the game's). Plus, the view distance is not infinite, but good enough for you to be able to spot obstacles and react to them in time.The "real" goal of the game is to get as high of a score as possible by collecting "tris", which are basically score multipliers. For every five tris you get, your multiplier will go up by one, but if you bump sideways into something you lose one. You lose the game when you crash into an obstacle or if your craft's battery is depleted due to lack of exposure to direct sunlight.There are some collectible items you can find as well, which can increase your speed temporarily, allow you to jump, skip the level or save you if you crash into something. A final thing to keep in mind is that there are some mini challenges that you need to complete in order to level up, which will, in turn, unlock collectibles, give you ship upgrades, a better starting multiplier, decals for your ship or make your existing upgrades better. I got to the maximum level in about 8 hours, but that's not where the game exhausts its content.If you wish to keep playing, there are plenty of things to keep you occupied: first off, the main game's world is reset every 24 hours, which means you have some time to learn the various obstacles during the day, but you will get a new challenge after you're done with it. Secondly, there are two other modes, one that is a considerably more difficult version of the standard world and another one that is actually a beatable maze, which I found to be a really cool alternative take on the core gameplay.And, last but not least, you can find some special portals on the levels, and those portals will lead you to an "alternate universe", which is basically a user-created level. And yes, there is an editor, of course.That's quite a bit of stuff for an indie game, right? Now, when it comes to the audiovisual aspects of the game, the graphics are really simple and streamlined (and, let's face it, somewhat outdated) but they have their charm, especially if you enjoy a "zen" sci-fi aesthetic. While the basic colors are gray, orange and white, the alternate worlds are much more varied and explosive in their visuals and can range from dying planets blowing up in front of you to star wars-esque space battles.The game's music begins as a calm but focused tune which slowly ramps up in intensity as the sun goes down, finishing in a downright violent manner in the later levels. It might get a little tiring after a while, but I find it to be pleasant to listen to either way.I think that's it, if you like racing, obstacle courses or simply want a new indie game to kill a few minutes every day with, this is definitely a good and cost-efficient choice.

content:
, 2014
												Mixed feelings. I bought this game to enjoy some high-speed flying in an open world, but in farther regions of it I actually don't get that much enjoyment because of dense, hazardous, and unforgiving landscape that keeps me crashing into something. The landscape has patterns, of course, and those patterns can be more or less efficiently learned after several runs (thus allowing you to improve your performance), but even a slightest mistake imminently turns out to be fatal. The aircraft's ability to steer left and right does not really match its acceleration; sometimes I feel like I could use a bit more agility.The gameplay itself is relatively simple; if you watched videos on the game's page in Steam store, then you've actually seen most of what it has to offer.If you are happy to exercise your quick reaction and fast reflexes, then you will probably find this game involving and worthy of your money. If, otherwise, you are not the best in making correct decisions in milliseconds, then you might prefer to look for the fun somewhere else.

												I am beginning to enjoy games that make it  easy to have a quick 3-5 minutes of gametime but still reward you with a solid gaming experience. The games that do this best are games that have randomly generated daily challenges, (i.e Spelunky , The binding of Issac etc) and Race the Sun accomplishes this perfectly. If played for longer than 20 minutes at a time it can be infuriating , but making the daily challenge a part of my gaming routine is enough to keep my reflexes sharp and honed as this game is all about reaction time and quick decision making. Simple yet smart art style takes me back to my days of playing Star Wars in the arcade with the vector styled graphics.  Definitely a must for those that enjoyed games like F-zero or Wipe-out.

content:
y 15
												If you played Barrier X, then this may bring to mind some pretty bad memories.  It's a game about focus, precision, and quick thinking.  One crash and it's OVER!  Oh, but that's not all...be prepared for some conditions that make life all the more difficult.Race the Sun is a game about playing as a solar-powered craft racing on to the infinity, but the problem is that you're only racing when the sun is in the sky...and it's sunset!!!  Shadows also slow you down...and if your battery runs out without you crashing, it's Game Over!Shadows, a descending sun, and moving obstacles that you can crash into.  Long story short, this is a rage game in the disguise of a game of simple design.  For the masochistic, there is an apocalypse mode where you're racing even faster than before (and a sun that descends even faster) that and a labyrinth mode with even more obstacles.  Just thinking about it gives me a headache!!!Now, you can aim for a high score, but that insists on you collecting blue objects without tapping into an obstacle.  As you level up, you will find powerups that can help you.  A magnet to collect points easier, an object that holds more jumps, an object that holds more revives (not that it'll matter)...don't expect them to save you for long, though.If you insist on getting this game, get it on sale.  Paying $10 just to be frustrated won't be worth losing your hair over.  (You can tear that out for free)3.5/10  Starts out simple, but ends in a crash!  (At least the program doesn't crash)

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
er 20, 2015
A Paladin’s Steam Review: Race the Sun. A Bit Slow Paced for A Fast Endless Runner.Genre: Minimalist Endless RacerDeveloped & Published by: Flippfly LLCPlatform: Windows, Mac, Linux and iOS. Business Model: Cheaper Base Game + Single Optional DLCCopy Purchased by Myself Overall Gameplay ThoughtsAs it says on the store page, Race the Sun has you driving a solar craft across a vast, endless space filled with obstacles galore. Your only timer is a constantly setting sun that you must race towards. If the sun sets or you get caught in a long shadow for too long, the craft will run out of power and the race is over. Each world is separated by regions that get progressively harder as more objects and obstacles are thrown into your path. Within certain districts are portals to optional levels to change the pace up. Workshop support allows you to try out community created worlds though I found these got a little too difficult for my taste. There’s also a leveling system where you need to complete goals (given to you in a set of three) every time you race. Some are pretty generic with completing a certain amount of score or reaching a certain district while others can be overly difficult (do a barrel roll 20 times in a single try, yeah, still can’t accomplish that task). Additionally, your solar craft can be configured with different attachments and badges. These are unlocked as you level up and seem to be quality of life changes to your craft, not real game changers.It’s a simplistic game where all you do is steer around objects and hit as many power ups (speed boosters and jump boosters are the most common) as you can. The high speed action takes some skill and split second decision making in order to be successful. Even then, you can easily get plastered against a wall for not reacting fast enough and that can get old fast. If there was a main complaint I’d have, it's that unlocks take way too long to get. Even after a couple of hours, I still haven’t gotten a single badge and there’s still more than half of the attachments left to unlock. There’s a constant sense of frustration at not getting much reward for making even the slightest amount of progress. I often got tired of doing the first region over and over again because I crashed on a simple rock at the beginning of the second region. I feel like there could be a better way of handling it but I have yet to see an endless runner do anything about it. Race the Sun does have procedurally generated levels but the structure is largely the same and all that really changes is what objects are in each district. RtS used to have daily challenges but they seem to have been patched out.  PC Settings and Sunrise DLCA fairly decent set of options can be found in Race the Sun. There’s a large amount of resolutions to choose from with fullscreen on/off. A quality slider that vaguely goes from fantastic to fastest. Vsync can be enabled/disabled. There’s two audio sliders for effects and music. Both a keyboard and a controller can be used and both work equally well. The keys can be rebound with optional secondaries. The Linux version seems to work quite well too. Anti-aliasing seems tied into the quality slider. I never had any performance problems or crashing. Video and audio work well together in this game too. The Sunrise DLC is for an optional world where there's no leaderboards, setting sun or optional objectives. It's ok but I kind of feel like its superfluous with multiple Workshop levels having the same rules. It at least looks quite pretty but I don't think $2 is worth pretty. Final ThoughtsRace the Sun has a good visual/audio design and it's one of the few endless runners I’ve run into that doesn’t try to waste your time with some nonsense business model. It's also a decently skillful runner too and has a good sense of speed, not dependent upon gimmicky controls or QTEs to slow you down. However, I find that the pacing is a little too long between unlocks. They can take far too long and too many runs to obtain and what you end up getting doesn't really change the game for the next hundred races. So, it can be a little too boring. If you’re ok with a repetitive endless run that isn’t looking to suck the money out of your wallet, Race the Sun is something to consider. Just don’t expect too much excitement and a lot of re-racing the first region. Read this review and more on A Paladin Without A Crusade[wp.me]

content:
y 24, 2014
												Simple yet elegant and fun game, your goal is to race towards the sun while avoiding obstacles.When you start playing the game you will realize you can only move left and right but you probably won't even finish the first stage on your few first tries since it's more complex than that, there's various obstacles that if you crash head-on will be instant death, and they get harder the further you go/the more the sun has set.Well, you probably would be done if that is all this game had to it, but hey, how about upgrades?You can level up by completing challenges set by the game which ranges from simple "score few points" to "complete a set number of  stages just turning left/right in a single run" which then will provide you with level-ups that will soon enable you to do such thing as jumps, adding a new dimension to game, unlocking new power-ups, a whole new difficulty (Apocalypse) for you tryhards, decals to customize your ships and few other things.Music is pretty nice too, the further you go the more the music get intense, and the feeling of acomplishment of getting further each run is really satisfying, then you ask: "So it's just another unlock upgrades or you aren't getting very far game?"to which I answer : "No."You probably can get very far without any upgrades if you know what obstacles are ahead and with a bit of planning.Another upside is that the stages changes everyday and you can create/play custom stages made by other players so there's replay value to be had.I would give it a 8/10, get it if you think the price tag is fine, or wait a sale to get it, but definetely support the devs for making such a cool game with a neat concept.

content:
y 3, 2015
												Why do you race the sun? What's the purpose? What are you trying to achieve? These questions will never once go through your head as you're travelling at light speed, avoiding obstacles, exploring surreal realms, and straying from the shadows that seek to slow your journey. This is not a game that you'll lose hours in, searching for rhyme or reason. This is a game you'll lose hours in, just trying to improve on your speed. A "pick up and go" game, as I like to call them. A game you'll no doubt come to every now and then, if only for a three minute session.Remember the original Starfox on the Super Nintendo? This is pretty much the same concept, except without lasers. It's a harback to those days of old, when gaming was just as addicting as it was immersive. You travel through an ever changing world at immense speeds, collecting items known as as "tris". But that's only to improve your multiplier. Perhaps the most fun of it is picking up powerups to make you go even faster, but you must avoid obstacles, take risky manuevers through thin narrow paths, and make split second decisions to avoid that one falling block that could destroy all your progress.With maps you can download from the workshop, the main Race The Sun map changes consistently, every 24 hours, to make each playthrough more or less difficult. And once you unlock portals to other dimensions, it makes the experience that more dynamic. It's not a thinking game as much as it is a reflex game.Also, I dare you to Race The Sun while drunk. Made for a competitive New Years.

content:
r 11, 2015
												Race the Sun has it's moments - the minimalistic world bring an abstract sense of beauty where I found myself compelled to play for some time.  But as a game it has some infuriating elements - had they been fixed would have truly set this game apart.The game's stages are randomly generated every day.  In theory this should bring a high level of replayability.  But after spending some time with the game you quickly begin to notice patterns of recycled elements rearranged through an endless loops.  This takes away from the sense of exploration and replaces it with predictability.Secondly the games leveling system doesn't encourage any real skill development.  You level up through completing sets of challenges - ranging in difficulty from way too easy to stupidly hard.  As a result you will level up more quickly by completing the easier challenges, but wont reward you with any sense of skill because of it.The game also backhandedly rewards leveling with ship upgrades that make achievements infinitely easier to obtain - but insults you for equiping them.  Atleast the developers had a sense of humor with anyone willing to play their game.Ultimately, this game sinks to the bottom of the ocean instead of reaching the sky.  While having an imaginative, beautiful and simplistic idea - it falters due to it's repetitive and grindy mechanics.  Also, the music sucks.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
9, 2015
												You'll find over 3,000 positive reviews for this game on Steam.  That's what happens when you give out a game for free that achieves what it sets out to do, albeit with a hefty serving of mediocrity.  This game is most certainly worth picking up for free or close to, but the $10 price tag?  That's pure arrogance.The game is an endless runner.  It's interesting and unique in its execution.  It feels smooth and is enjoyable to play.However, for $10, you would expect the level design to be somewhat more interesting than, "grey platonic solids randomly arrayed before a descending light source that tries to convey the majesty of a celestial body, but instead feels little more than a glorified night light, too dull to elicit any vibrancy from its environment."  This game advertises itself as one of those, "Feasts for the eyes and the mind," that seem to be trending in recent years.  It is not.  It is dull and grey.  It is fun, but it is not $10 fun.

content:
er 15, 2013
												OMG YES !!! This is the BEST Indie game that I have bought this year. I was very disappointed with promising games like Ring Runner, but this one is the real hidden gem. It's extremely addictive and despite the very simple and straightforward design, there is an amazing amount of depth to this game. I am digging the unlocks and simple ship configuration. I'm also looking forward to checking out player created words as well. The replayability factor is off the charts because the devs keep changing the world every 24 hours. Are you kidding me? Buy this game NOW. You will thank me right through the holidays.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
26, 2014
												This game is easy to recommend, especially for those that don't have much time to invest in a game and just want something easy and fun to play.Now the game is simple, what I mean by this is that the controls are straight forward and so is the main objective...race to the sun. The actual gameplay is a different factor, it can be VERY challenging in terms of actually making it far at least for me. The obstacles you'll be facing start off very easy but then turn extremely challenging and a lot of the times very cheap. Especially playing through it the first time, you will not be able to predict how to dodge the objects which means this game forces you into death until you learn the patterns. This was a little bit of a let down only because I was looking forward to reaction time playing a role here not just guess and check. To put it simple, you will die, you will die a lot. You will also try to avoid dieing but most of the time you'll have to do that in your second try. Does this put a damper on the game play? To an extend yes, but it doesn't hurt the over all game. The game looks great, plays great and frankly has some awesome moments that remind me of Journey. I'm sure there will be quite a few people that will enjoy playing this game on and off between classes, work or on lazy days.8.0/10 if you pick up during a sale and 7.5/10 if you purchase it at full price. Although the game is fun either way I feel that it didn't quite live up to the initial hype, but we did get a solid product!

content:
9, 2015
												You'll find over 3,000 positive reviews for this game on Steam.  That's what happens when you give out a game for free that achieves what it sets out to do, albeit with a hefty serving of mediocrity.  This game is most certainly worth picking up for free or close to, but the $10 price tag?  That's pure arrogance.The game is an endless runner.  It's interesting and unique in its execution.  It feels smooth and is enjoyable to play.However, for $10, you would expect the level design to be somewhat more interesting than, "grey platonic solids randomly arrayed before a descending light source that tries to convey the majesty of a celestial body, but instead feels little more than a glorified night light, too dull to elicit any vibrancy from its environment."  This game advertises itself as one of those, "Feasts for the eyes and the mind," that seem to be trending in recent years.  It is not.  It is dull and grey.  It is fun, but it is not $10 fun.

content:
ry 9, 2016
												A game of its own, it's a really interesting racer(?). It does well with its sun system, that will keep your vehicle moving if you go fast enough and keep the sun upgrades nearby at all times. It has some decent challenges, but the FOV at times can really make dodging things in an instant a bit heckling. It's a decent game, however I can't say if it's worth the price, since I got it for free on Day 1 launch. That's up to you to decide.Things to consider: -Do I want a game with replay value?-Do I want a game to boot up and play instantly when bored?-Do I not mind the price?-Does the workshop hold interest in me?If you answered "Yes" to at least two of these, go ahead. Overall?: 8/10. Great music, optimization, and easy-to-learn controls. It can easily hold interest whilst bored, but don't expect to be playing this for hours at a time.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
y 3, 2015
												Why do you race the sun? What's the purpose? What are you trying to achieve? These questions will never once go through your head as you're travelling at light speed, avoiding obstacles, exploring surreal realms, and straying from the shadows that seek to slow your journey. This is not a game that you'll lose hours in, searching for rhyme or reason. This is a game you'll lose hours in, just trying to improve on your speed. A "pick up and go" game, as I like to call them. A game you'll no doubt come to every now and then, if only for a three minute session.Remember the original Starfox on the Super Nintendo? This is pretty much the same concept, except without lasers. It's a harback to those days of old, when gaming was just as addicting as it was immersive. You travel through an ever changing world at immense speeds, collecting items known as as "tris". But that's only to improve your multiplier. Perhaps the most fun of it is picking up powerups to make you go even faster, but you must avoid obstacles, take risky manuevers through thin narrow paths, and make split second decisions to avoid that one falling block that could destroy all your progress.With maps you can download from the workshop, the main Race The Sun map changes consistently, every 24 hours, to make each playthrough more or less difficult. And once you unlock portals to other dimensions, it makes the experience that more dynamic. It's not a thinking game as much as it is a reflex game.Also, I dare you to Race The Sun while drunk. Made for a competitive New Years.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
r 11, 2015
												Race the Sun has it's moments - the minimalistic world bring an abstract sense of beauty where I found myself compelled to play for some time.  But as a game it has some infuriating elements - had they been fixed would have truly set this game apart.The game's stages are randomly generated every day.  In theory this should bring a high level of replayability.  But after spending some time with the game you quickly begin to notice patterns of recycled elements rearranged through an endless loops.  This takes away from the sense of exploration and replaces it with predictability.Secondly the games leveling system doesn't encourage any real skill development.  You level up through completing sets of challenges - ranging in difficulty from way too easy to stupidly hard.  As a result you will level up more quickly by completing the easier challenges, but wont reward you with any sense of skill because of it.The game also backhandedly rewards leveling with ship upgrades that make achievements infinitely easier to obtain - but insults you for equiping them.  Atleast the developers had a sense of humor with anyone willing to play their game.Ultimately, this game sinks to the bottom of the ocean instead of reaching the sky.  While having an imaginative, beautiful and simplistic idea - it falters due to it's repetitive and grindy mechanics.  Also, the music sucks.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:

												You'll find over 3,000 positive reviews for this game on Steam.  That's what happens when you give out a game for free that achieves what it sets out to do, albeit with a hefty serving of mediocrity.  This game is most certainly worth picking up for free or close to, but the $10 price tag?  That's pure arrogance.The game is an endless runner.  It's interesting and unique in its execution.  It feels smooth and is enjoyable to play.However, for $10, you would expect the level design to be somewhat more interesting than, "grey platonic solids randomly arrayed before a descending light source that tries to convey the majesty of a celestial body, but instead feels little more than a glorified night light, too dull to elicit any vibrancy from its environment."  This game advertises itself as one of those, "Feasts for the eyes and the mind," that seem to be trending in recent years.  It is not.  It is dull and grey.  It is fun, but it is not $10 fun.

content:
ber 21, 2014
												I almost dont recomend this game. Ill tell you why.Pros:The gameplay is very satisfying and the map is updated every day to provide a somewhat unique expirence.Controller support (Not a great game with keyboard).....errr yeah...Cons.For some mind boggling reason they locked a lot of the mechanics behind some arbitrary achivement like challenges. The power ups and collectables and upgrades for your ship are all locked behind this. I almost quit the game after 10 minutes until I realized this as the game was very boring.The whole Idea behind this is you have until the sun sets to get as far as you can. The only way to gain more time is by randomly placed yellow boost power ups. I dont like this. It means your runs are more luck based than skill. I would have prefered the blue 'score' pickups to have gained you more time instead.That being said. There is only one game mode and one map. There is no story and no tutorial. It feels the game is lacking a large amount of content. There is a mod support but I cant be bothered to sort through all the mods to find some more maps to play. If the devs dont want to put in the effort then why should I?The do update the map everyday to change it but the same assets are used... just moved around. So even though it is techniqually different, it feels the same.Final thoughtThe gameplay that is there is very satisfying and fun. It's just a shame that that is all there is to it. I would love to see some actual content added here. If you see it on a sale go ahead and pick it up.

content:
14, 2014
												For such a simple game, there is a lot to like. Race The Sun provides hours of intense and rapid racing through sci-fi inspired, randomly daily generated worlds. It's also not without its flaws, mostly due to extremely slow developer patching and updating, or lack thereof.Race The Sun is great in short bursts, even though it may also be enjoyed for a couple hours at a time. It's not that it becomes repetitive and boring, it's that it becomes frustrating, as once you've advanced past ten or so regions, it quickly becomes very difficult and demanding of your reflexes. Being that some of us aren't cheating and aren't that young anymore, keeping up with the top of the leaderboard can be a daunting task. Since the world is regenerated and the leaderboard reset for each day, the competition is usually fresh and there's always a new challenge awaiting you. You don't need to play every day to have fun. It's this natural "pick up and play" aspect of Race The Sun that is most enjoyable. Sometimes you can't seem to do very well in a certain generated world. Other times, you'll be able to finish the day in the top ten and feel accomplished. Because of these daily variations, the game never gets old.Unfortunately, there are some major problems that have never been addressed as of yet, and even though the developers have acknowledged the need for patching and updating the major problems, there hasn't been any actual progress. The leaderboards have been malfunctioning, or sometimes completely broken since release, and nothing has been done about it so far. Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't. Sometimes it becomes so bugged that your scores and dates will become scrambled and confused, only to apparently go back to normal next time you play the game. There is very little point in playing a score attack game when the leaderboards are often not working properly or not working at all. The other problem with the leaderboards comes with cheating. The developers have mentioned an eventual replay system for the highest scores in order to discourage some players' cheating ways. Sadly, as I've already mentioned, the major patch and update is still nowhere to be found, even though these major problems have been present since release.It may seem like this review's complaints outnumber compliments, but in reality, even with its major flaws, Race The Sun really is a fun game. Even if it never gets fixed, I still plan on keeping it installed and going back to it every once in a while. It's probably the best of the genre right now. Too bad it's imperfect.Race The Sun is good.

												I have played this game for a few hours over a coupe of days and it is awesome. The controls are simple (so far it's left, right and when you have a jump spacebar / A (on controller)) They feel about right once you get use to the senstivity.The difficulty increases with each region you get through - within the first hour of play I went from barely passing region 1 to perfect region 1 and 2 and making it through 3 into region 4. If that wasnt' crazy enough I unlocked Armageddon mode and it quickly humbled me. The world resets every 24 hours so there are new challenges every day with the new map to explore.I've played with a controller and keyboard - both feel very good - I prefer controller myself though.I had a few issues getting it to start - but the support from the developement team was very quick and thorough - my issues are resolved and the game runs very smooth...now I just need time to practice so I can go for top scores.

content:
y 25, 2015
												Reminds me of the old 3D vector racing games, you simply have to continue on chasing that sun in the distance without hitting obstacles. It also has some interesting mechanics such as your ship's power comes from solar energy, meaning if you spend too long in the dark you won't even need to worry about crashing, you will come to a complete halt. There are also pickups that extend the time it takes for the sun to set helping you keep your sun energy high and I enjoyed this teeter-totter style play where I frequently shift my eyes all around the screen hunting for pickups while trying to concentrate on my ship and the obstacles ahead. The maps are also generated daily and this keeps the replayability levels quite high whether you play for a few runs a day or hours at a time.In short: I'd rate it around a 7. The graphics are simplistic but quite plain at the beginning which doesn't really appeal to me.
